item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electroreductive Intramolecular Heck‐Type Cyclization for the Synthesis of Benzofused Oxygenated Heterocycles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Conventional synthetic routes to benzofused oxygenated heterocycles, such as Dihydrobenzofuran, chromane and isochromane derivatives, often involve complex synthetic conditions, high costs, and environmental concerns. The key to addressing this challenge lies in achieving transition‐metal‐free C(sp²)–I bond cleavage to enable intramolecular radical cyclization. Inspired by electroreductive strategies, we developed a convenient, transition‐metal‐free electroreductive tandem reaction for synthesizing dihydrobenzofuran, chromane, and isochromane derivatives. Comprehensive evaluation demonstrates that our approach not only simplifies synthetic conditions but also suppresses competing hydrogenation and halogenation pathways at the exocyclic carbon radical center.
item.content:encoded: Conventional synthetic routes to benzofused oxygenated heterocycles, such as Dihydrobenzofuran, chromane and isochromane derivatives, often involve complex synthetic conditions, high costs, and environmental concerns. The key to addressing this challenge lies in achieving transition-metal-free C(sp²)–I bond cleavage to enable intramolecular radical cyclization. Inspired by electroreductive strategies, we developed a convenient, transition-metal-free electroreductive tandem reaction for synthesizing dihydrobenzofuran, chromane, and isochromane derivatives. Comprehensive evaluation demonstrates that our approach not only simplifies synthetic conditions but also suppresses competing hydrogenation and halogenation pathways at the exocyclic carbon radical center.
item.dc:creator: Yan Yu, Xin Wang, Yicheng Zhang, Kuai Wang, Ling-Guo Meng
item.dc:title: Electroreductive Intramolecular Heck‐Type Cyclization for the Synthesis of Benzofused Oxygenated Heterocycles

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Improved Chemical Synthesis of Avenanthramides Family and its Analogs by Mixed Anhydride Method
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Amides derived from common hydroxycinnamic acids — including 4‐hydroxycinnamic acid, 3‐methoxy‐4‐hydroxycinnamic acid, 3,4‐dihydroxycinnamic acid, 3,4‐dimethoxycinnamic acid, and 3,4,5‐trimethoxycinnamic acid — along with various free aminobenzoic acids, such as 5‐hydroxy‐2‐aminobenzoic acid, a key component of the avenanthramide family, have been rapidly synthesized using an innovative, environmentally friendly synthetic methodology. This approach, grounded in traditional chemistry, utilizes mixed anhydrides to simultaneously protect and activate hydroxycinnamic acids through the actions of triethylamine and isobutyl chloroformate while employing acetone as a green solvent. The resulting amides, formed from the coupling with free aromatic amino acids, are constructed as O‐carbonate‐protected derivatives with high yields and purity, isolated directly via crystallization, thus eliminating chromatographic or HPLC purifications. Furthermore, free phenols can be conveniently released on demand using morpholine in methanol. Under these conditions, C‐protected aromatic amino acids remain unacylated. This synthetic strategy represents a significant advancement over conventional acyl chloride methodologies, which often rely on toxic reagents and solvents and entail time‐consuming and complex procedures. It enhances the production of important phytochemicals such as Avenanthramides and opens doors to various analogs, paving the way for potential pharmacological applications.

This approach, grounded in traditional chemistry, utilizes mixed anhydrides to simultaneously protect and activate hydroxycinnamic acids through the actions of triethylamine and isobutyl chloroformate while employing acetone as a green solvent. The resulting amides, formed from the coupling with free aromatic amino acids, are constructed as O-carbonate-protected derivatives with high yields and purity, isolated directly via crystallization, thus eliminating chromatographic or HPLC purifications. item.dc:title: Improved Chemical Synthesis of Avenanthramides Family and its Analogs by Mixed Anhydride Method

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent developments and perspectives in Palladium‐catalyzed Multi‐component Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Multi‐component reactions (MCRs) involve the reaction of three or more compounds to yield a single product. Typically, MCRs are eco‐friendly and atom‐economical processes, widely used to synthesize pharmaceutically relevant compounds with diverse applications in both medicinal and synthetic chemistry. Nowadays, transition metals are widely used as catalysts in MCRs due to their exceptional ability to create both C‐C and C‐heteroatom bonds. Metal‐catalyzed MCRs offer optimal chemical diversity, excellent atom economy, and energy savings.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Unsymmetrical Bis(Phosphine) Monoxides and N‐Heterocyclic Carbene‐Phosphine Oxides through Michaelis–Arbuzov Reactions of Phosphinite Esters
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The Michaelis–Arbuzov reaction of dihaloalkanes with methyl dialkylphosphinite esters provides a modular approach to bis(phosphine) monoxide ligands with different substituents on the two phosphorus centers. The intermediate haloalkylphosphine oxide reacts with N‐arylimidazoles to give phosphine oxide‐substituted N‐heterocyclic carbene ligand precursors.
A modular synthesis of bis(phosphine) monoxide (BPMO) ligands has been realized using the Michaelis–Arbuzov reaction of dialkylphosphinite esters. The modular synthetic method allows the chemoselective synthesis of BPMO ligands in which the substituents on the two phosphorus centers are different. This methodology also provides a route to N‐heterocyclic carbene‐phosphine oxide ligand precursors.
item.content:encoded:
The Michaelis–Arbuzov reaction of dihaloalkanes with methyl dialkylphosphinite esters provides a modular approach to bis(phosphine) monoxide ligands with different substituents on the two phosphorus centers. The intermediate haloalkylphosphine oxide reacts with N-arylimidazoles to give phosphine oxide-substituted N-heterocyclic carbene ligand precursors.


A modular synthesis of bis(phosphine) monoxide (BPMO) ligands has been realized using the Michaelis–Arbuzov reaction of dialkylphosphinite esters. The modular synthetic method allows the chemoselective synthesis of BPMO ligands in which the substituents on the two phosphorus centers are different. This methodology also provides a route to N-heterocyclic carbene-phosphine oxide ligand precursors.

item.dc:title: Synthesis of Unsymmetrical Bis(Phosphine) Monoxides and N‐Heterocyclic Carbene‐Phosphine Oxides through Michaelis–Arbuzov Reactions of Phosphinite Esters

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Silver‐Mediated Cascade Synthesis of Open‐Cage Fullerenes from C60 and Propargylic Carbonates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: In recent years, open‐cage fullerenes (i.e., fullerene derivatives featuring an orifice within their cage structure) have attracted significant attention across multiple research areas in materials, coordination, supramolecular, and biomolecular chemistry. However, the methodology available for the preparation of open‐cage fullerenes remains limited. In this study, it was discovered that upon heating fullerene C60 with propargylic carbonates in the presence of silver trifluoroacetate, a cascade of reaction steps was initiated, resulting in the one‐step synthesis of the corresponding open‐cage bisfulleroids. Moreover, the feasibility of introducing various substituents via this methodology was confirmed. Notably, the proposed protocol facilitates the synthesis of bisfulleroid derivatives, wherein a hydrogen atom resides on one side of the bridgehead carbon at the orifice, while an aryl or alkyl substituent is strategically introduced on the opposite side. This approach provides structural diversity for the synthesis of open‐cage fullerenes, and is expected to promote the widespread application of open‐cage fullerene derivatives.

In this study, it was discovered that upon heating fullerene C60 with propargylic carbonates in the presence of silver trifluoroacetate, a cascade of reaction steps was initiated, resulting in the one-step synthesis of the corresponding open-cage bisfulleroids. Moreover, the feasibility of introducing various substituents via this methodology was confirmed. Notably, the proposed protocol facilitates the synthesis of bisfulleroid derivatives, wherein a hydrogen atom resides on one side of the bridgehead carbon at the orifice, while an aryl or alkyl substituent is strategically introduced on the opposite side. This approach provides structural diversity for the synthesis of open-cage fullerenes, and is expected to promote the widespread application of open-cage fullerene derivatives.

item.dc:title: Silver‐Mediated Cascade Synthesis of Open‐Cage Fullerenes from C60 and Propargylic Carbonates

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: SnCl2‐Catalyzed Phosphorylation of Alcohols and Selective Phosphorylation/Phosphinoylation of Carbohydrates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Phosphorylated molecules, particularly phosphorylated carbohydrates, have garnered significant interest due to their distinct biological activities, driving an urgent demand for efficient phosphorylation strategies. In this study, we demonstrate the successful development of a SnCl2‐catalyzed protocol for the phosphorylation of alcohols and carbohydrates. Notably, the reaction efficiency was found to be critically dependent on the addition order of SnCl2 and N,N‐diisopropylethylamine, a phenomenon systematically investigated through mechanistic studies. A one‐pot sequential ketalization/phosphorylation strategy was established for polyol substrates, enabling streamlined access to phosphorylated derivatives. The versatility of this approach was further exemplified by achieving selective phosphorylation/phosphinoylation of carbohydrates.
item.content:encoded: Phosphorylated molecules, particularly phosphorylated carbohydrates, have garnered significant interest due to their distinct biological activities, driving an urgent demand for efficient phosphorylation strategies. In this study, we demonstrate the successful development of a SnCl2-catalyzed protocol for the phosphorylation of alcohols and carbohydrates. Notably, the reaction efficiency was found to be critically dependent on the addition order of SnCl2 and N,N-diisopropylethylamine, a phenomenon systematically investigated through mechanistic studies. A one-pot sequential ketalization/phosphorylation strategy was established for polyol substrates, enabling streamlined access to phosphorylated derivatives. The versatility of this approach was further exemplified by achieving selective phosphorylation/phosphinoylation of carbohydrates.
item.dc:creator: Hai Dong, Jian Lv, Chun-Yang Liu, Xiaorui Zhang, Shuang-Xi Gu
item.dc:title: SnCl2‐Catalyzed Phosphorylation of Alcohols and Selective Phosphorylation/Phosphinoylation of Carbohydrates

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Chiral β‐Lactams by Ruthenium‐Catalyzed Enantioselective CH Carbene Insertion
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A ruthenium‐catalyzed C(sp3)H carbene insertion leads to the enantioselective formation of chiral β‐lactams in up to 82% isolated yield and excellent enantioselectivities up to 98% enantiomeric excess without any indication of a competing Buchner reaction. The reaction is catalyzed by a new ruthenium complex containing a chiral pyridine‐2,6‐bis(oxazoline) ligand in combination with a cyclometalated phenylimidazo[1,5‐a]pyridine ligand.
A ruthenium‐catalyzed intramolecular carbenoid insertion into a C(sp3)H bond leads to the enantioselective formation of chiral β‐lactams. The reaction is catalyzed by a ruthenium complex featuring a chiral pyridine‐2,6‐bis(oxazoline) ligand, combined with a cyclometalated phenylimidazo[1,5‐a]pyridine ligand. This complex belongs to a recently introduced new class of ruthenium catalysts (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2020, 59, 12393). Starting from N‐benzyl α‐diazoacetamides, chiral β‐lactams are provided in up to 82% isolated yield with up to 98% enantiomeric excess, without any occurrence of a Buchner side reaction. Mechanistic experiments reveal that β‐lactam (4‐membered ring) formation is inherently favored over the more common γ‐lactam (5‐membered ring) formation.
item.content:encoded:
A ruthenium-catalyzed C(sp3)H carbene insertion leads to the enantioselective formation of chiral β-lactams in up to 82% isolated yield and excellent enantioselectivities up to 98% enantiomeric excess without any indication of a competing Buchner reaction. The reaction is catalyzed by a new ruthenium complex containing a chiral pyridine-2,6-bis(oxazoline) ligand in combination with a cyclometalated phenylimidazo[1,5-a]pyridine ligand.


A ruthenium-catalyzed intramolecular carbenoid insertion into a C(sp3)H bond leads to the enantioselective formation of chiral β-lactams. The reaction is catalyzed by a ruthenium complex featuring a chiral pyridine-2,6-bis(oxazoline) ligand, combined with a cyclometalated phenylimidazo[1,5-a]pyridine ligand. This complex belongs to a recently introduced new class of ruthenium catalysts (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2020, 59, 12393). Starting from N-benzyl α-diazoacetamides, chiral β-lactams are provided in up to 82% isolated yield with up to 98% enantiomeric excess, without any occurrence of a Buchner side reaction. Mechanistic experiments reveal that β-lactam (4-membered ring) formation is inherently favored over the more common γ-lactam (5-membered ring) formation.
item.dc:creator: Anna Lena Opper, Xin Nie, Sergei I. Ivlev, Eric Meggers
item.dc:title: Chiral β‐Lactams by Ruthenium‐Catalyzed Enantioselective CH Carbene Insertion

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of β‐Hydroxy‐α,α‐dimethyl Carboxylic Esters via Asymmetric Barbier Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Despite the occurrence of the β‐hydroxy‐α,α‐dimethyl carboxylic ester motif in many natural products no attempt was made to synthesize this core structure via a racemic and enantioselective Barbier reaction. In this study, the optimized reaction conditions for the achiral Barbier reaction between allyl bromide and a 2,2‐dimethyl‐3‐oxopropanoate were found, yielding the desired β‐hydroxy‐α,α‐dimethyl carboxylic ester in up to 64%. Therefore, different metals, additives, solvents and solvent mixtures were tested. The optimized reaction conditions were then used to expand the substrate scope of the Barbier reaction by using five structurally different allylic and propargylic bromides. By using (+)‐cinchonine and (–)‐cinchonidine as chiral additives along with indium in a THF / hexane solvent mixture it was possible to obtain ten different β‐hydroxy‐α,α‐dimethyl carboxylic esters in an enantioenriched fashion with up to 81% yield and 98%ee.
item.content:encoded: Despite the occurrence of the β-hydroxy-α,α-dimethyl carboxylic ester motif in many natural products no attempt was made to synthesize this core structure via a racemic and enantioselective Barbier reaction. In this study, the optimized reaction conditions for the achiral Barbier reaction between allyl bromide and a 2,2-dimethyl-3-oxopropanoate were found, yielding the desired β-hydroxy-α,α-dimethyl carboxylic ester in up to 64%. Therefore, different metals, additives, solvents and solvent mixtures were tested. The optimized reaction conditions were then used to expand the substrate scope of the Barbier reaction by using five structurally different allylic and propargylic bromides. By using (+)-cinchonine and (–)-cinchonidine as chiral additives along with indium in a THF / hexane solvent mixture it was possible to obtain ten different β-hydroxy-α,α-dimethyl carboxylic esters in an enantioenriched fashion with up to 81% yield and 98%ee.
item.dc:creator: Jan Grammel, Jasmina Amrouch, Wolfgang Frey, Anna Zens, Sabine Laschat
item.dc:title: Synthesis of β‐Hydroxy‐α,α‐dimethyl Carboxylic Esters via Asymmetric Barbier Reaction

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Total Syntheses of the Linearly‐Fused Prenylated Indole Alkaloids Asperversiamides H and M via Oxidative Rearrangement of the Putative Biosynthetic Precursor Dihydrocarneamide A
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: An improved synthesis of the alkaloid dihydrocarneamide A is reported and this has been subjected to a biomimetic‐type oxidative rearrangement using an oxaziridine and so affording the spiro‐oxidole‐containing and prenylated indole alkaloids (PIAs) asperversiamides H and M. This work serves to confirm the structure assigned to the latter. Oxidation of dihydrocarneamide A using m‐chloroperbenzoic (m‐CPBA) afforded an oxidative fragmentation product representing the linear isomer of the PIA amoenamide A and thus a potential "natural product in‐waiting". Furthermore, oxaziridine‐mediated oxidation of the epimer of dihydrocarneamide A (and the enantiomer of the structure assigned to the natural product asperversiamide F) afforded a mixture of two hitherto unreported spiro‐oxindoles. Given the manner in which these last two products have been formed it seems likely that these, too, are "natural products in‐waiting". Certain cytotoxic and anti‐microbial properties of key compounds are reported.
item.content:encoded: An improved synthesis of the alkaloid dihydrocarneamide A is reported and this has been subjected to a biomimetic-type oxidative rearrangement using an oxaziridine and so affording the spiro-oxidole-containing and prenylated indole alkaloids (PIAs) asperversiamides H and M. This work serves to confirm the structure assigned to the latter. Oxidation of dihydrocarneamide A using m-chloroperbenzoic (m-CPBA) afforded an oxidative fragmentation product representing the linear isomer of the PIA amoenamide A and thus a potential "natural product in-waiting". Furthermore, oxaziridine-mediated oxidation of the epimer of dihydrocarneamide A (and the enantiomer of the structure assigned to the natural product asperversiamide F) afforded a mixture of two hitherto unreported spiro-oxindoles. Given the manner in which these last two products have been formed it seems likely that these, too, are "natural products in-waiting". Certain cytotoxic and anti-microbial properties of key compounds are reported.
item.dc:creator: Martin Banwell, Zhongnan Xu, Xinru Li, Shen Tan, Shenting Zhang, Wenzhu Yu
item.dc:title: Total Syntheses of the Linearly‐Fused Prenylated Indole Alkaloids Asperversiamides H and M via Oxidative Rearrangement of the Putative Biosynthetic Precursor Dihydrocarneamide A

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxidative Cyclization of 1,7‐Dienes Induced by α‐Oxyalkyl/Acyl Radicals to Access Functionalized Benzo[b]azepin‐2‐ones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A metal‐free cascade oxidative cyclization method has been developed for synthesizing functionalized benzo[b]azepin2‐ones from 1,7‐dienes using alcohols, ethers, or aryl aldehydes. The reaction generates α‐oxyalkyl or acyl radicals by direct C(sp3)−H or C(sp2)−H cleavage, avoiding photocatalysts and transition metals. This approach offers a mild strategy for the synthesis of benzo[b]azepine derivatives with high atom economy and efficiency. Mechanistic studies, including radical trapping and HRMS analysis, confirmed a radical‐mediated pathway involving cyclization and single‐electron transfer.
item.content:encoded: A metal-free cascade oxidative cyclization method has been developed for synthesizing functionalized benzo[b]azepin2-ones from 1,7-dienes using alcohols, ethers, or aryl aldehydes. The reaction generates α-oxyalkyl or acyl radicals by direct C(sp3)−H or C(sp2)−H cleavage, avoiding photocatalysts and transition metals. This approach offers a mild strategy for the synthesis of benzo[b]azepine derivatives with high atom economy and efficiency. Mechanistic studies, including radical trapping and HRMS analysis, confirmed a radical-mediated pathway involving cyclization and single-electron transfer.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: An Electrochemical Method for Decarboxylative Halogenation of Aryl Propynoic Acids with Potassium Halides under Transition‐Metal‐Free Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: We report herein an electrochemical method for decarboxylative halogenation of aryl propynoic acids under transition‐metal‐free conditions. In an undivided cell, diverse aryl propynoic acids and KX were employed to synthesize a series of haloalkynes. Mechanistic studies demonstrated the possible involvement of a free‐radical intermediate in the transformation.
item.content:encoded: We report herein an electrochemical method for decarboxylative halogenation of aryl propynoic acids under transition-metal-free conditions. In an undivided cell, diverse aryl propynoic acids and KX were employed to synthesize a series of haloalkynes. Mechanistic studies demonstrated the possible involvement of a free-radical intermediate in the transformation.
item.dc:creator: Zhengjiang Fu, Fei Han, Junhua Zeng, Hu Cai
item.dc:title: An Electrochemical Method for Decarboxylative Halogenation of Aryl Propynoic Acids with Potassium Halides under Transition‐Metal‐Free Conditions

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in Transition Metal‐Catalyzed/Mediated C−SCF3 Bond Formation Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The trifluoromethylthiolated group (SCF3) is characterized by its strong electron‐withdrawing ability, excellent lipophilicity, good stability, and bioavailability, making it highly relevant for applications in drug design and development. This review summarizes recent advances in C−X (H, Cl, OTf, B(OH)2) trifluoromethylthiolation reaction from 2014 to 2024. The discussion is organized into three major sections: 1) transition metal‐catalyzed C−H trifluoromethylthiolation reactions facilitated by directing groups (DGs), 2) transition metal‐catalyzed trifluoromethylthiolation via cross‐coupling reactions, and 3) light‐assisted transition metal‐catalyzed trifluoromethylthiolation reactions. Additionally, this review examines the substrate scope, limitations, and partial mechanisms associated with these transformations.
item.content:encoded: The trifluoromethylthiolated group (SCF3) is characterized by its strong electron-withdrawing ability, excellent lipophilicity, good stability, and bioavailability, making it highly relevant for applications in drug design and development. This review summarizes recent advances in C−X (H, Cl, OTf, B(OH)2) trifluoromethylthiolation reaction from 2014 to 2024. The discussion is organized into three major sections: 1) transition metal-catalyzed C−H trifluoromethylthiolation reactions facilitated by directing groups (DGs), 2) transition metal-catalyzed trifluoromethylthiolation via cross-coupling reactions, and 3) light-assisted transition metal-catalyzed trifluoromethylthiolation reactions. Additionally, this review examines the substrate scope, limitations, and partial mechanisms associated with these transformations.
item.dc:creator: Peng Xu, Xulong Qin
item.dc:title: Recent Advances in Transition Metal‐Catalyzed/Mediated C−SCF3 Bond Formation Reaction

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible Light‐Driven E‐Selective Semihydrogenation of Alkynes and Their Application in the Treatment of Glioblastoma Multiforme
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A visible light‐driven E‐selective semihydrogenation scheme of alkyne compounds is developed for designing and synthesizing glioblastoma multiforme inhibitors. The representative reaction mechanism is decoded through theoretical calculations and deuteration experiments.
A visible light‐driven E‐selective semihydrogenation scheme of alkyne compounds is developed for designing and synthesizing glioblastoma multiforme inhibitors. Herein, room‐temperature semihydrogenation reactions of various alkyne compounds are successfully achieved under the irradiation of white light. The representative reaction mechanism is decoded through theoretical calculations and deuteration experiments, revealing the critical roles played by [Ir(Cp‐Me5)Cl2]2, PdCl2, DPPE and TEOA as photosensitizer, catalyst, ligand, and electron donor, respectively. This method exhibits excellent E‐selectivity and broad functional group compatibility and demonstrates its practical value by producing pinosylvin and its derivatives with strong inhibitory effects on U87 cells.
item.content:encoded:
A visible light-driven E-selective semihydrogenation scheme of alkyne compounds is developed for designing and synthesizing glioblastoma multiforme inhibitors. The representative reaction mechanism is decoded through theoretical calculations and deuteration experiments.


A visible light-driven E-selective semihydrogenation scheme of alkyne compounds is developed for designing and synthesizing glioblastoma multiforme inhibitors. Herein, room-temperature semihydrogenation reactions of various alkyne compounds are successfully achieved under the irradiation of white light. The representative reaction mechanism is decoded through theoretical calculations and deuteration experiments, revealing the critical roles played by [Ir(Cp-Me5)Cl2]2, PdCl2, DPPE and TEOA as photosensitizer, catalyst, ligand, and electron donor, respectively. This method exhibits excellent E-selectivity and broad functional group compatibility and demonstrates its practical value by producing pinosylvin and its derivatives with strong inhibitory effects on U87 cells.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Total Synthesis of Ectocarpin A
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A total enantioselective synthesis of Ectocarpin A, an oxylipin identified through the first hydroperoxide bicyclase activity of CYP5164A3 in brown algae, has been successfully completed in 12 steps starting from tetrahydro‐1H‐cyclopentafuranone. Key transformations include the creation of the chiral tetrahydro‐1H‐cyclopentafuranone, a diastereoselective epoxidation, an enzymatic desymmetrization of a 1,4‐diol, an epimerization, and both Wittig and Julia‐Kocienski olefinations to build the carbon framework of Ectocarpin A.
item.content:encoded: A total enantioselective synthesis of Ectocarpin A, an oxylipin identified through the first hydroperoxide bicyclase activity of CYP5164A3 in brown algae, has been successfully completed in 12 steps starting from tetrahydro-1H-cyclopentafuranone. Key transformations include the creation of the chiral tetrahydro-1H-cyclopentafuranone, a diastereoselective epoxidation, an enzymatic desymmetrization of a 1,4-diol, an epimerization, and both Wittig and Julia-Kocienski olefinations to build the carbon framework of Ectocarpin A.
item.dc:creator: Alexandre Guy, Thierry Durand, Camille Oger
item.dc:title: Total Synthesis of Ectocarpin A

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Substituted Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines, Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyrazines and Imidazo[1,2‐b]pyridazines by Multicomponent Reactions Using Green Solvents.
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Here we describe the synthesis of imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines, imidazo[1,2‐a]pyrazines and imidazo[1,2‐b]pyridazines by multicomponent Groebke‐Blackburn‐Bienaymé (GBB) reaction under sustainable conditions using eucalyptol as green solvent. After determining the optimum conditions for catalysis, a library of 32 compounds with activity on the central nervous system was quickly and efficiently assembled.
item.content:encoded: Here we describe the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines, imidazo[1,2-a]pyrazines and imidazo[1,2-b]pyridazines by multicomponent Groebke-Blackburn-Bienaymé (GBB) reaction under sustainable conditions using eucalyptol as green solvent. After determining the optimum conditions for catalysis, a library of 32 compounds with activity on the central nervous system was quickly and efficiently assembled.
item.dc:creator: Sabine Berteina-Raboin, Abdelkarim El-Qami, Gatien Messire, Gaëtan Bouchery, Emma Caillet, Sloan Steiner
item.dc:title: Synthesis of Substituted Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines, Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyrazines and Imidazo[1,2‐b]pyridazines by Multicomponent Reactions Using Green Solvents.

item.title: Enantioselective Anion‐Binding‐Catalyzed Nucleophilic Addition to 4‐Quinolones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Chiral quinolones and their derivatives are predominant synthetic building blocks and pharmacological agents. Nevertheless, their synthesis mostly relies on transition‐metal‐catalyzed enantioselective 1,4‐additions of organometallic reagents such as Grignard, organozinc or organoboron species for alkylation, arylation and alkynylation reactions. Herein, we report the first organocatalytic enantioselective formal 1,4‐addition to challenging 4‐quinolones upon in situ silylation to the corresponding quinolinium ions, followed by asymmetric nucleophilic attack to this type of substrates. This method complements previous metal catalyzed approaches by enrolling enol nucleophiles and relies on anion‐binding catalysis using a chiral triazole‐based anion binder. The enantioenriched 2‐substituted 2,3‐dihydro‐4‐quinolones were thus obtained in good yields (up to 97% yield) and enantioselectivities up to 89:11 e.r. Finally, the easy access to 4‐amino and γ−amino alcohol derivatives by post functionalization, as well as to enantiopure compounds (>99:1 e.r.) was showcased. The notable feature of this protocol includes its mild reaction conditions, avoiding the use of transition metals, broad functional group tolerance and potential application towards the synthesis chiral 2,3‐dihydro‐4‐quinolones and tetrahydroquinolines as important skeletons of bioactive and natural products.

Herein, we report the first organocatalytic enantioselective formal 1,4-addition to challenging 4-quinolones upon in situ silylation to the corresponding quinolinium ions, followed by asymmetric nucleophilic attack to this type of substrates. This method complements previous metal catalyzed approaches by enrolling enol nucleophiles and relies on anion-binding catalysis using a chiral triazole-based anion binder. The enantioenriched 2-substituted 2,3-dihydro-4-quinolones were thus obtained in good yields (up to 97% yield) and enantioselectivities up to 89:11 e.r. Finally, the easy access to 4-amino and γ−amino alcohol derivatives by post functionalization, as well as to enantiopure compounds (>99:1 e.r.) was showcased. The notable feature of this protocol includes its mild reaction conditions, avoiding the use of transition metals, broad functional group tolerance and potential application towards the synthesis chiral 2,3-dihydro-4-quinolones and tetrahydroquinolines as important skeletons of bioactive and natural products.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Rh(III)‐Catalyzed Cascade [3 + 3] Spiroannulation of N‐Acyl Ketimines with Iodonium Ylides: Access to Spiro‐N,O‐Ketals
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This study presents a Rh(III)‐catalyzed cascade [3 + 3] spiroannulation for the synthesis of spiro‐N,O‐ketals starting from 3‐hydroxy‐3‐arylisoindolin‐1‐ones and iodonium ylides in “one‐pot” with high yields and excellent chemo‐ and stereoselectivity. The protocol demonstrates broad substrate tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable tool for the synthesis of bioactive molecules and complex natural products.
A Rh(III)‐catalyzed cascade CH activation/[3 + 3]spiroannulation of 3‐hydroxy‐3‐arylisoindolin‐1‐ones with iodonium ylides has been developed. The method facilitates the efficient and selective construction of spirocyclic compounds in a one‐pot manner, offering high yields and excellent conversion. The reaction proceeds via a highly regioselective process, resulting in the formation of spiro‐N,O‐ketals with remarkable chemo‐ and stereoselectivity. This strategy provides a valuable protocol for the synthesis of complex spirocyclics with potential applications in medicinal chemistry and materials science.
item.content:encoded:

The protocol demonstrates broad substrate tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable tool for the synthesis of bioactive molecules and complex natural products.


A Rh(III)-catalyzed cascade CH activation/[3 + 3]spiroannulation of 3-hydroxy-3-arylisoindolin-1-ones with iodonium ylides has been developed. The method facilitates the efficient and selective construction of spirocyclic compounds in a one-pot manner, offering high yields and excellent conversion. This strategy provides a valuable protocol for the synthesis of complex spirocyclics with potential applications in medicinal chemistry and materials science.

item.title: Brønsted Acid‐Promoted Tandem Cyclization/Addition of Enaminones with H‐Phosphine Oxides for Synthesis of C2‐Phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐Chromones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones is discovered via Brønsted acid‐promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H‐phosphine oxides. Various C2‐phosphorylated products 3 and 4 are smoothly constructed in excellent yields, providing a novel strategy for C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones.
A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones is discovered via Brønsted acid‐promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H‐phosphine oxides. The reaction exhibits a broad scope, good functional group tolerance, and good yields, and features ability of a gram‐scaled synthesis. Results of mechanistic study reveal that the reaction initially undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which can subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones through intermolecular addition.
item.content:encoded:

Various C2-phosphorylated products 3 and 4 are smoothly constructed in excellent yields, providing a novel strategy for C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones.


A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones is discovered via Brønsted acid-promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H-phosphine oxides. The reaction exhibits a broad scope, good functional group tolerance, and good yields, and features ability of a gram-scaled synthesis. Results of mechanistic study reveal that the reaction initially undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which can subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones through intermolecular addition.

item.title: Ni‐Catalyzed Cross‐Electrophile Couplings of N‐Alkoxyphthalimides and Aryl Halides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
N‐Alkoxyphthalimides represent a versatile class of redox‐active alcohol derivatives for the formation of new carbon–carbon bonds. Herein, key precedents using N‐alkoxyphthalimides for new carbon–carbon bond formation under photochemical reaction conditions are first presented. The merger of single‐electron activation strategies with Ni‐catalysis in select cross‐electrophile couplings is then highlighted. Concluding thoughts for future reaction design are also presented.
N‐alkoxyphthalimides represent a versatile class of redox‐active alcohol derivatives for carbon–carbon bond formation following activation by single‐electron reduction. Herein, key precedents using N‐alkoxyphthalimides for the formation of new carbon–carbon bonds under photochemical reaction conditions are first presented. The merger of these and other single‐electron activation strategies with Ni catalysis in various cross‐electrophile couplings with aryl halides is then highlighted. A particular focus is made on the mechanisms proposed for these Ni‐catalyzed reductive cross‐couplings. Concluding thoughts for future reaction design using N‐alkoxyphthalimides as redox‐active C(sp3)O derivatives in transition metal‐catalyzed cross‐couplings are also presented.
item.content:encoded:
N-Alkoxyphthalimides represent a versatile class of redox-active alcohol derivatives for the formation of new carbon–carbon bonds. Herein, key precedents using N-alkoxyphthalimides for new carbon–carbon bond formation under photochemical reaction conditions are first presented. The merger of single-electron activation strategies with Ni-catalysis in select cross-electrophile couplings is then highlighted. Concluding thoughts for future reaction design are also presented.


N-alkoxyphthalimides represent a versatile class of redox-active alcohol derivatives for carbon–carbon bond formation following activation by single-electron reduction. Herein, key precedents using N-alkoxyphthalimides for the formation of new carbon–carbon bonds under photochemical reaction conditions are first presented. The merger of these and other single-electron activation strategies with Ni catalysis in various cross-electrophile couplings with aryl halides is then highlighted. A particular focus is made on the mechanisms proposed for these Ni-catalyzed reductive cross-couplings. Concluding thoughts for future reaction design using N-alkoxyphthalimides as redox-active C(sp3)O derivatives in transition metal-catalyzed cross-couplings are also presented.

item.title: Advances in Sulfenamide Chemistry: Synthetic Strategies and Reactivity Profiles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Sulfenamides, as S(II) compounds, occupy a critical role in modern synthetic chemistry, driven by their multifaceted applications across pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and diverse industrial sectors. Functioning as versatile intermediates, sulfenamides facilitate a broad array of transformations, including oxidation, amination, and sulfuration, underscoring their utility in complex molecular construction. This review presents an in‐depth analysis of sulfenamide synthesis, reactivity patterns, and multifarious applications, with a particular focus on recent mechanistic insights and prospective advances poised to shape the next generation of sulfenamide chemistry

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrocatalytic Selenylation of 2‐Alkenylanilines for the Synthesis of 3‐Selanylindoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: An electrocatalytic cascade selenylation/oxidation of 2‐alkenylanilines enabling the assembly of various 2‐aryl‐3‐selanylindoles in one‐pot under chemical‐oxidant‐free and transition‐metal‐free conditions was disclosed. A series of functional 3‐selanylindoles were smoothly furnished in acceptable yields. This electrocatalytic strategy was flexibly suitable for diverse diaryl diselenides and 2‐alkenylanilines. This method was highlighted by broad substrate scope, good functional group compatibility, mild conditions, and easy operation. The preliminarily mechanistic experiments suggested that a radical pathway was probably involved in this protocol.
item.content:encoded: An electrocatalytic cascade selenylation/oxidation of 2-alkenylanilines enabling the assembly of various 2-aryl-3-selanylindoles in one-pot under chemical-oxidant-free and transition-metal-free conditions was disclosed. A series of functional 3-selanylindoles were smoothly furnished in acceptable yields. This electrocatalytic strategy was flexibly suitable for diverse diaryl diselenides and 2-alkenylanilines. This method was highlighted by broad substrate scope, good functional group compatibility, mild conditions, and easy operation. The preliminarily mechanistic experiments suggested that a radical pathway was probably involved in this protocol.

item.dc:title: Electrocatalytic Selenylation of 2‐Alkenylanilines for the Synthesis of 3‐Selanylindoles

item.title: Chemical and Biosynthetic Evolution of Quadrane and Related Sesquiterpenoids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Through the evolution of biosynthetic enzymes, the bioactivity‐relevant chemical space of natural products has been significantly expanded. In this concept, we summarize the recent progress in elucidating the intriguing chemical and biosynthetic evolution of fungal‐derived quadrane sesquiterpene scaffolds including humulene, caryophyllene, presilphiperfolan‐8‐ol, silphinene, and terrecyclene, offering opportunities to discover novel sesquiterpenoids through genome mining.
Abstract Natural products, with their potent bioactivities and selectivities, significantly benefit human health and agriculture. The evolution of biosynthetic enzymes of natural products has greatly expanded their chemical space relevant to bioactivity. Insights from natural evolution provide valuable guidance for engineering these enzymes to create molecules with novel structures and bioactivities. Recent studies have unveiled an intriguing biosynthetic evolution of fungal‐derived quadrane sesquiterpene scaffolds, indicating evolutionary relationships among sesquiterpene scaffolds such as humulene, caryophyllene, presilphiperfolan‐8‐ol, silphinene, and terrecyclene, rooted in their biosynthetic mechanisms. This review summarizes recent progress in the discovery and biosynthetic characterization of these sesquiterpenoids. These findings illuminate the logic behind the chemical and biosynthetic evolution of sesquiterpenes and offer opportunities to discover new sesquiterpenoids through genome mining.
item.content:encoded:
Through the evolution of biosynthetic enzymes, the bioactivity-relevant chemical space of natural products has been significantly expanded. In this concept, we summarize the recent progress in elucidating the intriguing chemical and biosynthetic evolution of fungal-derived quadrane sesquiterpene scaffolds including humulene, caryophyllene, presilphiperfolan-8-ol, silphinene, and terrecyclene, offering opportunities to discover novel sesquiterpenoids through genome mining.


Abstract

Natural products, with their potent bioactivities and selectivities, significantly benefit human health and agriculture. The evolution of biosynthetic enzymes of natural products has greatly expanded their chemical space relevant to bioactivity. Insights from natural evolution provide valuable guidance for engineering these enzymes to create molecules with novel structures and bioactivities. Recent studies have unveiled an intriguing biosynthetic evolution of fungal-derived quadrane sesquiterpene scaffolds, indicating evolutionary relationships among sesquiterpene scaffolds such as humulene, caryophyllene, presilphiperfolan-8-ol, silphinene, and terrecyclene, rooted in their biosynthetic mechanisms. This review summarizes recent progress in the discovery and biosynthetic characterization of these sesquiterpenoids. These findings illuminate the logic behind the chemical and biosynthetic evolution of sesquiterpenes and offer opportunities to discover new sesquiterpenoids through genome mining.

item.title: Synthesis of Dispiro‐[Indoline‐3,1′‐Cyclopropane‐2′,3′′‐Indoline]‐2,2′′‐Diones via Thermal [2+1] Cycloaddition Between 3‐Alkylidene‐7‐Aza‐2‐Indolones and 3‐Diazo‐7‐Aza‐2‐Oxindoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Diastereoselective synthesis of highly substituted dispiro‐[indoline‐3,1′‐cyclopropane‐2′,3′′‐indoline]‐2,2′′‐dione in excellent yield via an unusual [2+1]‐cycloaddition of 3‐alkylidene‐7‐aza‐2‐indolones and 3‐diazo‐7‐aza‐2‐oxindoles under neat condition has been developed. A plausible mechanism invoking a carbene and alkene cyclization is proposed. This approach includes mild conditions, substrate tolerance, scope, high yields, and selectivity.
Abstract Diastereoselective synthesis of highly substituted dispiro‐[indoline‐3,1′‐cyclopropane‐2′,3′′‐indoline]‐2,2′′‐dione in excellent yield via an unusual catalyst‐free thermal [2+1]‐cycloaddition of E‐3‐alkylidene‐7‐aza‐2‐indolones and 3‐diazo‐7‐aza‐2‐oxindoles under neat condition has been developed. The advantages of the approach include mild reaction conditions, substrate tolerance, broad scope, high yields, and selectivity of the reaction. A plausible reaction mechanism invoking a carbene intermediate and alkene [2+1]‐cyclization is proposed.
item.content:encoded:
Diastereoselective synthesis of highly substituted dispiro-[indoline-3,1′-cyclopropane-2′,3′′-indoline]-2,2′′-dione in excellent yield via an unusual [2+1]-cycloaddition of 3-alkylidene-7-aza-2-indolones and 3-diazo-7-aza-2-oxindoles under neat condition has been developed. A plausible mechanism invoking a carbene and alkene cyclization is proposed. This approach includes mild conditions, substrate tolerance, scope, high yields, and selectivity.


Abstract

Diastereoselective synthesis of highly substituted dispiro-[indoline-3,1′-cyclopropane-2′,3′′-indoline]-2,2′′-dione in excellent yield via an unusual catalyst-free thermal [2+1]-cycloaddition of E-3-alkylidene-7-aza-2-indolones and 3-diazo-7-aza-2-oxindoles under neat condition has been developed. The advantages of the approach include mild reaction conditions, substrate tolerance, broad scope, high yields, and selectivity of the reaction. A plausible reaction mechanism invoking a carbene intermediate and alkene [2+1]-cyclization is proposed.

item.dc:title: Synthesis of Dispiro‐[Indoline‐3,1′‐Cyclopropane‐2′,3′′‐Indoline]‐2,2′′‐Diones via Thermal [2+1] Cycloaddition Between 3‐Alkylidene‐7‐Aza‐2‐Indolones and 3‐Diazo‐7‐Aza‐2‐Oxindoles

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Effect of Substituents on the Tautomerism of Pyridone Nucleoside Analogs
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Experimental and quantum‐chemical work shows that the predominant tautomer of 6‐fluoropyridones is the lactim, not the lactam form. This makes them analogs of cytosine, not uracil or thymine in the context of incorporation opposite complementary bases of genetic sequences.
Abstract Nucleobase analogs are important tools in medicine and chemical biology, as they offer molecular targeting options for the intervention in genetic processes. Pyridone C‐nucleosides have been shown to pair with adenine in complementary strands, but a switch from the lactam to lactim form may change their base pairing preference. We synthesized 6‐fluoropyridone analogs of aciclovir and cidofovir, which we assumed to be in the lactam form, but were found to lack activity against hepatitis B virus (HBV). Spectroscopic data then indicated that they are predominantly in the lactim form, with a hydrogen bonding pattern suitable for G. The tautomerism of fluoropyridones was then studied by UV‐spectroscopy and quantum‐chemical calculations. The UV spectroscopic pattern for either tautomer was corroborated by synthesizing N‐ and O‐methylated model compounds, and measuring their spectra. The tautomeric equilibrium of selected other substituted pyridones is predicted, based on density‐functional theory calculations.
item.content:encoded:
Experimental and quantum-chemical work shows that the predominant tautomer of 6-fluoropyridones is the lactim, not the lactam form. This makes them analogs of cytosine, not uracil or thymine in the context of incorporation opposite complementary bases of genetic sequences.


Abstract

Nucleobase analogs are important tools in medicine and chemical biology, as they offer molecular targeting options for the intervention in genetic processes. Pyridone C-nucleosides have been shown to pair with adenine in complementary strands, but a switch from the lactam to lactim form may change their base pairing preference. We synthesized 6-fluoropyridone analogs of aciclovir and cidofovir, which we assumed to be in the lactam form, but were found to lack activity against hepatitis B virus (HBV). Spectroscopic data then indicated that they are predominantly in the lactim form, with a hydrogen bonding pattern suitable for G. The tautomerism of fluoropyridones was then studied by UV-spectroscopy and quantum-chemical calculations. The UV spectroscopic pattern for either tautomer was corroborated by synthesizing N- and O-methylated model compounds, and measuring their spectra. The tautomeric equilibrium of selected other substituted pyridones is predicted, based on density-functional theory calculations.
item.dc:creator: Leon Stark, Patrik Zielinski, Burkhard Miehlich, Shangqing Yang, Wolfgang Frey, Ralf Bartenschlager, Andreas Köhn, Clemens Richert
item.dc:title: Effect of Substituents on the Tautomerism of Pyridone Nucleoside Analogs

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A New Approach Towards the Synthesis of Imidazol‐4‐Ones Using α‐Diazoesters and Hydrazide Catalysed by Cu(I) Salt
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A new synthetic strategy for the preparation of imidazol‐4‐ones from hydrazides and α‐diazoesters using Cu(I) metal catalyst is reported. In the absence of the Cu(I) catalyst or even utilising any other metal catalyst, the unexpected imine bond formation between the terminal nitrogen of hydrazide and carbene carbon was observed. The reaction proceeds via the cleavage of the C−N bond of the hydrazide.
Abstract Imidazole and substituted imidazoles have drawn much attention owing to their superior biological functions. In this regard, devising a synthetic strategy to improve viability, easy to handle and more yield is challenging task for synthetic chemists. Herein we report a new synthetic strategy for the synthesis of imidazol‐4‐ones from hydrazides and α‐diazoesters using Cu(I) metal catalyst. In the absence of the Cu(I) catalyst or even utilizing any other metal catalyst, the imine bond formation between the terminal N of hydrazides and carbene was observed. The reaction proceeds via the cleavage of the C−N bond of the hydrazide followed by cyclization and yielded the expected product. We have also explored the substrate scope of our strategy and obtained excellent yields. We have isolated the products in pure form and fully characterized them using sophisticated analytical and spectroscopic techniques including single crystal X‐Ray analysis.
item.content:encoded:
A new synthetic strategy for the preparation of imidazol-4-ones from hydrazides and α-diazoesters using Cu(I) metal catalyst is reported. In the absence of the Cu(I) catalyst or even utilising any other metal catalyst, the unexpected imine bond formation between the terminal nitrogen of hydrazide and carbene carbon was observed. The reaction proceeds via the cleavage of the C−N bond of the hydrazide.


Abstract

Imidazole and substituted imidazoles have drawn much attention owing to their superior biological functions. In this regard, devising a synthetic strategy to improve viability, easy to handle and more yield is challenging task for synthetic chemists. Herein we report a new synthetic strategy for the synthesis of imidazol-4-ones from hydrazides and α-diazoesters using Cu(I) metal catalyst. In the absence of the Cu(I) catalyst or even utilizing any other metal catalyst, the imine bond formation between the terminal N of hydrazides and carbene was observed. The reaction proceeds via the cleavage of the C−N bond of the hydrazide followed by cyclization and yielded the expected product. We have also explored the substrate scope of our strategy and obtained excellent yields. We have isolated the products in pure form and fully characterized them using sophisticated analytical and spectroscopic techniques including single crystal X-Ray analysis.

item.dc:title: A New Approach Towards the Synthesis of Imidazol‐4‐Ones Using α‐Diazoesters and Hydrazide Catalysed by Cu(I) Salt

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: An Approach to Functionalization of Cucurbit[n]uril Through a Tetrahydrothiopheno Equatorial Substituent
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The inclusion of a tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril provides an avenue to reactive derivatization. This process extends the potential for future applications of the cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. Also highlighted are new glycoluril derivatives that may serve as precursors in the synthesis of cucurbit[n]uril or their analogues.
Abstract A tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril was found to be robust and provided a capacity for reactive derivatization. We have demonstrated this on tetrahydrothiopheno substituted glycoluril derivatives as a proof of concept, then translatable reactions were applied to tetrahydrothiopheno substituted cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. In addition to the successful derivatization tetrahydrothiophenocucurbit[7 and 8]uril, some new glycoluril derivatives have been synthesized, which may serve as future precursors for the synthesis of other substituted cucurbit[n]uril and their analogues.
item.content:encoded:
The inclusion of a tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril provides an avenue to reactive derivatization. This process extends the potential for future applications of the cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. Also highlighted are new glycoluril derivatives that may serve as precursors in the synthesis of cucurbit[n]uril or their analogues.


Abstract

A tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril was found to be robust and provided a capacity for reactive derivatization. We have demonstrated this on tetrahydrothiopheno substituted glycoluril derivatives as a proof of concept, then translatable reactions were applied to tetrahydrothiopheno substituted cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. In addition to the successful derivatization tetrahydrothiophenocucurbit[7 and 8]uril, some new glycoluril derivatives have been synthesized, which may serve as future precursors for the synthesis of other substituted cucurbit[n]uril and their analogues.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Enantioselective Construction of Tetrahydro‐α‐Carbolines via Organocatalytic Friedel‐Crafts Alkylation/N‐Hemiacetalization of 2‐Aminoindoles with Enals
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An efficient organocatalytic asymmetric Friedel‐Crafts alkylation/N‐hemiacetalization reaction of 2‐aminoindoles with α,β‐unsaturated aldehydes has been established. This mild and effective synthetic method exhibits a wide substrate scope, facilitating the synthesis of chiral tetrahydro‐α‐carbolines with potential biological activity.
Abstract An efficient organocatalytic asymmetric Friedel‐Crafts alkylation/N‐hemiacetalization reaction of 2‐aminoindoles with α,β‐unsaturated aldehydes was developed. By incorporating an amino group at the C2 position of indole, the nucleophilicity of the C3 position of indole and the amino group were leveraged to generate an enamine‐type ternary synthon. This approach enabled the construction of a range of chiral tetrahydro‐α‐carboline skeletons with potential biological activity, delivering moderate to excellent yields (46–83 %) and achieving outstanding enantioselectivity (up to 99 % ee).
item.content:encoded:
An efficient organocatalytic asymmetric Friedel-Crafts alkylation/N-hemiacetalization reaction of 2-aminoindoles with α,β-unsaturated aldehydes has been established. This mild and effective synthetic method exhibits a wide substrate scope, facilitating the synthesis of chiral tetrahydro-α-carbolines with potential biological activity.


Abstract

An efficient organocatalytic asymmetric Friedel-Crafts alkylation/N-hemiacetalization reaction of 2-aminoindoles with α,β-unsaturated aldehydes was developed. By incorporating an amino group at the C2 position of indole, the nucleophilicity of the C3 position of indole and the amino group were leveraged to generate an enamine-type ternary synthon. This approach enabled the construction of a range of chiral tetrahydro-α-carboline skeletons with potential biological activity, delivering moderate to excellent yields (46–83 %) and achieving outstanding enantioselectivity (up to 99 % ee).

item.dc:title: Enantioselective Construction of Tetrahydro‐α‐Carbolines via Organocatalytic Friedel‐Crafts Alkylation/N‐Hemiacetalization of 2‐Aminoindoles with Enals

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Three‐Component α‐Thienylation/Oxylation Cascade of IIII/SVI‐Ylides via Photoinduced EDA Complex Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Herein we report a visible‐light‐induced three‐component cascade of α‐thienylation/oxylation of IIII/SVI‐ylides, substituted thiophenes and alcohols to afford α‐thienyl‐α′‐oxyl ketone derivatives. The key of the strategy involves electron‐donor‐acceptor (EDA) complex formation between IIII/SVI‐ylides and electron‐rich thiophenes and the generation of unprecedented sulfoxonium ylide radical upon light irradiation.
Abstract Herein, a visible‐light‐induced three‐component cascade of α‐thienylation/oxylation of IIII/SVI‐ylides, substituted thiophenes and alcohols is reported. The core of the strategy involves electron‐donor‐acceptor (EDA) complex formation between IIII/SVI‐ylides and electron‐rich thiophenes. Upon photo‐activation, IIII/SVI‐ylides in‐situ generates sulfoxonium ylide radical, which is trapped by thiophenes to generate α‐thienyl‐α’‐ketyl sulfoxonium ylides and initiated subsequent carbenic O−H insertion from alcohol component. All reactions are operationally simple and proceed smoothly under mild reaction conditions, affording a broad range of unsymmetrical α,α‐disubstituted ketones in moderate to good yields.
item.content:encoded:
Herein we report a visible-light-induced three-component cascade of α-thienylation/oxylation of IIII/SVI-ylides, substituted thiophenes and alcohols to afford α-thienyl-α′-oxyl ketone derivatives. The key of the strategy involves electron-donor-acceptor (EDA) complex formation between IIII/SVI-ylides and electron-rich thiophenes and the generation of unprecedented sulfoxonium ylide radical upon light irradiation.


Abstract

Herein, a visible-light-induced three-component cascade of α-thienylation/oxylation of IIII/SVI-ylides, substituted thiophenes and alcohols is reported. The core of the strategy involves electron-donor-acceptor (EDA) complex formation between IIII/SVI-ylides and electron-rich thiophenes. Upon photo-activation, IIII/SVI-ylides in-situ generates sulfoxonium ylide radical, which is trapped by thiophenes to generate α-thienyl-α’-ketyl sulfoxonium ylides and initiated subsequent carbenic O−H insertion from alcohol component. All reactions are operationally simple and proceed smoothly under mild reaction conditions, affording a broad range of unsymmetrical α,α-disubstituted ketones in moderate to good yields.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Pot, Three‐Component Borrowing Hydrogen/Cyclization Synthesis of Benzimidazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Co complexes (Salen Co‐NHPI) with Salen, organic nitrogen hydroxyl groups efficiently catalyze the one‐pot, three‐component synthesis of benzimidazoles from nitrobenzene, benzyl alcohol, and sulfonyl azide.
Abstract Multicomponent reactions are an efficient toolbox of access to complex compounds, but the development of multicomponent reactions involved in benzimidazole synthesis is still limited. Herein, a one‐pot, three‐component reaction involving nitrobenzene, benzyl alcohol, and sulfonyl azide was developed for the synthesis of benzimidazoles employing Co‐complexes (Salen Co‐NHPI) as catalyst, which by self‐assembly from salen ligands, organic nitrogen hydroxyl compounds, and CoCl2. Compared with previously reported three‐component methods for the construction of benzimidazoles, this method involves a novel hydrogen borrowing/cyclization and can provide a variety of benzimidazole in moderate to excellent yields.
item.content:encoded:
Co complexes (Salen Co-NHPI) with Salen, organic nitrogen hydroxyl groups efficiently catalyze the one-pot, three-component synthesis of benzimidazoles from nitrobenzene, benzyl alcohol, and sulfonyl azide.


Abstract

Multicomponent reactions are an efficient toolbox of access to complex compounds, but the development of multicomponent reactions involved in benzimidazole synthesis is still limited. Herein, a one-pot, three-component reaction involving nitrobenzene, benzyl alcohol, and sulfonyl azide was developed for the synthesis of benzimidazoles employing Co-complexes (Salen Co-NHPI) as catalyst, which by self-assembly from salen ligands, organic nitrogen hydroxyl compounds, and CoCl2. Compared with previously reported three-component methods for the construction of benzimidazoles, this method involves a novel hydrogen borrowing/cyclization and can provide a variety of benzimidazole in moderate to excellent yields.

item.title: Cover Feature: A New Approach Towards the Synthesis of Imidazol‐4‐Ones Using α‐Diazoesters and Hydrazide Catalysed by Cu(I) Salt (Eur. J. Org. Chem. 14/2025)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description: The Cover Feature shows the synthesis of imidazol‐4‐ones from α‐diazoesters and hydrazides, catalyzed by a CuI catalyst. The two boats symbolize the reaction pathway, each carrying the same two passengers: α‐diazoester and hydrazide. In the absence of a catalyst, the journey leads to the formation of an imine. However, under the influence of “clouds”, representing the CuI catalyst, the reaction takes a different course, resulting in the formation of imidazol‐4‐ones. More information can be found in the Research Article by C. Sivasankar and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.202401395). Artwork by all the authors.

item.title: Design Concepts and Synthesis Strategies for Porous Organic Polymers‐Based Catalysts: Targeting the in‐situ Conversion of Low‐concentration CO2 into Value‐added Chemicals
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This paper reviews the latest advancements in POPs‐based catalysts application for in‐situ conversion of low‐concentration CO2 into value‐added chemicals, dissecting the design concepts, preparation methods, structural characteristics, and performance parameters of the catalysts. The synthesis strategies include homopolymerization, copolymerization, Friedel‐Crafts alkylation, Schiff base condensation, phenol‐formaldehyde condensation, and cyano trimerization condensation reactions.
Abstract Porous organic polymers (POPs)‐based catalysts have emerged as promising materials for the conversion of low‐concentration CO2 into valuable chemicals, leveraging their high specific surface area, designability, multifunctionality, exceptional stability, and eco‐friendliness. This comprehensive review synthesizes the latest advancements in POPs‐based catalysts application for in‐situ conversion of low‐concentration CO2 into value‐added chemicals, dissecting the design concepts, preparation methods, structural characteristics, and performance parameters of the catalysts. The synthesis strategies include homopolymerization, copolymerization, Friedel‐Crafts alkylation, Schiff base condensation, phenol‐formaldehyde condensation, and cyano trimerization condensation reactions. This paper also provides a forward‐looking perspective on the potential future developments within this domain. The goal is to lay a robust scientific groundwork for driving technological innovation and to illuminate the path for future research in this burgeoning field.

Abstract

Porous organic polymers (POPs)-based catalysts have emerged as promising materials for the conversion of low-concentration CO2 into valuable chemicals, leveraging their high specific surface area, designability, multifunctionality, exceptional stability, and eco-friendliness. This comprehensive review synthesizes the latest advancements in POPs-based catalysts application for in-situ conversion of low-concentration CO2 into value-added chemicals, dissecting the design concepts, preparation methods, structural characteristics, and performance parameters of the catalysts. The synthesis strategies include homopolymerization, copolymerization, Friedel-Crafts alkylation, Schiff base condensation, phenol-formaldehyde condensation, and cyano trimerization condensation reactions. This paper also provides a forward-looking perspective on the potential future developments within this domain. The goal is to lay a robust scientific groundwork for driving technological innovation and to illuminate the path for future research in this burgeoning field.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in Visible Light‐Driven Multicomponent Reactions of Aryl Diazonium Tetrafluoroborates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 14, April 7, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Photoreactions have been widely used in multicomponent. This review highlights recent advances in multicomponent photochemical reactions using aryl diazonium tetrafluoroborate as a starting material for synthesizing a variety of useful organic compounds.
Abstract Photochemical multicomponent reactions are a valuable technology in modern synthetic chemistry. These reactions utilize visible light as a clean and renewable energy source, enabling the construction of diverse molecules from multiple substrates in a single step. These advantages have driven the application of multicomponent photochemical reactions in various fields such as drug discovery, materials science, and agrochemical development. Recently, aryl diazonium tetrafluoroborates have emerged as promising substrates for photochemical multicomponent reactions, and they have been used to synthesize a variety of complex compounds through photochemical multicomponent reactions. This review highlights recent advances in visible light‐induced multicomponent reactions employing aryl diazonium tetrafluoroborates.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Deprotection and Functionalization of Protective N‐Heterocycles Under Mild Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A mild protocol for the deprotection and further functionalization of N‐heterocycles in a single operation is discovered in the presence of potassium trimethylsilanolate and butyronitrile. A variety of N‐heterocycles containing various protecting groups can be compatible with good yields and functional group tolerance under ambient conditions. The methodology features high efficiency, simple operation, and further application.
A mild and versatile potassium trimethylsilanolate/butyronitrile (KOTMS/PrCN) reaction system for the deprotection and further functionalization of N‐heterocycles in a single step is developed. A range of N‐heterocycles, attached by various protecting groups, can be well transformed with good yields and functionality tolerance. The protocol features high efficiency, simple operation, and synthetic application.

item.title: Manganese‐Catalyzed Synthesis of Tetrahydropyridines via Borrowing Hydrogen Strategy
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Tetrahydropyridines are versatile compounds widely used in organic synthesis and drug manufacturing. Herein, a manganese‐catalyzed borrowing hydrogen coupling of 1‐substituted ethanol derivatives with γ‐amino alcohols is reported. This novel protocol has a broad substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and affords a diverse library of valuable 2,6‐disubstituted tetrahydropyridines in moderate to good yields. Mechanistically, the reaction proceeds sequentially through catalytic dehydrogenation, dual cross‐condensation, and further hydrogenation of the formed unsaturated intermediates to yield the desired tetrahydropyridines.

item.title: Recent Developments for the Ring Opening of Pyrrolidines and Unstrained Cyclic Amines via C−N Bond Cleavage
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review highlights recent advancements in the deconstructive transformation of unstrained cyclic amines, with a particular focus on the C−N bond cleavage of pyrrolidines. Various methodologies, including von Braun‐type, oxidative, and reductive approaches, facilitate the synthesis of diverse amines and the expansion of chemical space. These developments emphasize the transformative potential of skeletal remodeling, offering innovative strategies for drug discovery.
Abstract In recent years, the deconstructive transformation of unstrained cyclic amines via C−N bond cleavage has emerged as a powerful strategy for expanding chemical space and facilitating the synthesis of structurally diverse molecules. Notably, advancements in the C−N bond cleavage of pyrrolidine and other unstrained cyclic amines have highlighted the significant potential of this approach in modern organic synthesis. This concept reviews recent developments in the C−N bond cleavage reaction, with a primary focus on pyrrolidines, while also exploring broader progress in related systems.

These developments emphasize the transformative potential of skeletal remodeling, offering innovative strategies for drug discovery.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Nonenzymatic Carboxylate Phosphorylation in Water
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The phosphorylation of carboxylic acids to acyl phosphates is a recurring reaction in the core of microbial metabolism, a set of processes thought to date back to the origins of life. This study shows that carboxylate phosphorylation occurs in water without enzymes or adenosine triphosphate (ATP), enabled by diamidophosphate and nitrite.
The core pathways of autotrophic microbial metabolism have been proposed to be fossils of self‐organized prebiotic chemistry. In recent years, numerous reactions within these pathways have been shown to occur nonenzymatically, supporting this hypothesis. However, the phosphorylation of carboxylic acids to the corresponding acyl phosphates, a recurring metabolic reaction, has notably yet to be demonstrated without enzymes. Here, this study shows that carboxylate phosphorylation is promoted by diamidophosphate and sodium nitrite in the presence of water, driven by the release of dinitrogen. The reaction occurs in minutes at 0–50 °C to convert carboxylic acids to acyl amidophosphate intermediates, which then undergo nitrite‐promoted hydrolysis to give the corresponding acyl phosphates. The partial overlap in scope with important metabolic carboxylates and the concentrated acidic conditions likely limit its direct applicability in metabolic origins of life scenarios. Nonetheless, the work represents a step forward in understanding nonenzymatic carboxylate phosphorylation and helps clarify how the transformation might eventually be rendered compatible with a protometabolism.
item.content:encoded:

This study shows that carboxylate phosphorylation occurs in water without enzymes or adenosine triphosphate (ATP), enabled by diamidophosphate and nitrite.


The core pathways of autotrophic microbial metabolism have been proposed to be fossils of self-organized prebiotic chemistry. In recent years, numerous reactions within these pathways have been shown to occur nonenzymatically, supporting this hypothesis. However, the phosphorylation of carboxylic acids to the corresponding acyl phosphates, a recurring metabolic reaction, has notably yet to be demonstrated without enzymes. Here, this study shows that carboxylate phosphorylation is promoted by diamidophosphate and sodium nitrite in the presence of water, driven by the release of dinitrogen. The reaction occurs in minutes at 0–50 °C to convert carboxylic acids to acyl amidophosphate intermediates, which then undergo nitrite-promoted hydrolysis to give the corresponding acyl phosphates. The partial overlap in scope with important metabolic carboxylates and the concentrated acidic conditions likely limit its direct applicability in metabolic origins of life scenarios. Nonetheless, the work represents a step forward in understanding nonenzymatic carboxylate phosphorylation and helps clarify how the transformation might eventually be rendered compatible with a protometabolism.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Divergent One‐Pot Two‐Step Synthesis of Phosphoryl‐Substituted 4‐Quinolones and 3‐Indolinones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
New methodology is being developed for the divergent synthesis of phosphonylated 4‐quinolones and phosphonylated 3‐indolinones based on phosphoryl‐substituted ynones bearing (2‐iodoaryl) group using controlled addition of anilines to them followed by Cu‐catalyzed cyclization.
Herein, an approach is developed for the selective two‐step synthesis of phosphoryl‐substituted 4‐quinolones and phosphoryl‐substituted 3‐indolinones. This is achieved through the reaction of (3‐(2‐iodoaryl)‐3‐oxoprop‐1‐yn‐1‐yl)phosphonates with anilines followed by Cu‐catalyzed intramolecular cyclization of the intermediately formed regioisomeric enamines, which are selectively formed under neat conditions or in the presence of a gold complex as a catalyst. This method allows for the synthesis of a series of phosphoryl‐substituted 4‐quinolones and phosphoryl‐substituted 3‐indolinones in good yields.
item.content:encoded:
New methodology is being developed for the divergent synthesis of phosphonylated 4-quinolones and phosphonylated 3-indolinones based on phosphoryl-substituted ynones bearing (2-iodoaryl) group using controlled addition of anilines to them followed by Cu-catalyzed cyclization.


Herein, an approach is developed for the selective two-step synthesis of phosphoryl-substituted 4-quinolones and phosphoryl-substituted 3-indolinones. This is achieved through the reaction of (3-(2-iodoaryl)-3-oxoprop-1-yn-1-yl)phosphonates with anilines followed by Cu-catalyzed intramolecular cyclization of the intermediately formed regioisomeric enamines, which are selectively formed under neat conditions or in the presence of a gold complex as a catalyst. This method allows for the synthesis of a series of phosphoryl-substituted 4-quinolones and phosphoryl-substituted 3-indolinones in good yields.
