item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Unlocking Indazole Synthesis from α‐Diazo‐β‐Ketoesters via Aryne Trapping: A Streamlined Approach
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
To address the growing demand to develop, beyond laboratory scale, more efficient, safer and ecofriendly, as well as scalable mechanochemical transformations, the direct synthesis of 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles via α‐diazo‐β‐ketoesters aryne trapping is reported. The results reveal the unexpected formation of N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates, likely facilitated by a thia‐fries rearrangement. Density functional theory calculations elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the various reaction products.
Indazoles are high‐value chemical building blocks used in medicinal chemistry and materials science for their distinct structural and functional features. This study details a [3 + 2]‐cycloaddition reaction between various aryl‐ketodiazoesters and ortho‐(trimethylsilyl)aryl triflates under mild conditions, leading predominantly to 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles. N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates are also observed as other products. The reaction exhibits broad functional group tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable synthetic approach. Mechanistic insights, derived from control experiments and density functional theory calculations, elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the products. Collectively, these findings underscore the method's potential for synthesizing complex indazole derivatives, which hold significant promises for applications in pharmaceutical development and advanced materials research.
item.content:encoded:
To address the growing demand to develop, beyond laboratory scale, more efficient, safer and ecofriendly, as well as scalable mechanochemical transformations, the direct synthesis of 1-acyl-1H-indazoles via α-diazo-β-ketoesters aryne trapping is reported. The results reveal the unexpected formation of N-aryl-1H-indazoles and aryl benzoates, likely facilitated by a thia-fries rearrangement. Density functional theory calculations elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the various reaction products.


Indazoles are high-value chemical building blocks used in medicinal chemistry and materials science for their distinct structural and functional features. This study details a [3 + 2]-cycloaddition reaction between various aryl-ketodiazoesters and ortho-(trimethylsilyl)aryl triflates under mild conditions, leading predominantly to 1-acyl-1H-indazoles. N-aryl-1H-indazoles and aryl benzoates are also observed as other products. The reaction exhibits broad functional group tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable synthetic approach. Mechanistic insights, derived from control experiments and density functional theory calculations, elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the products. Collectively, these findings underscore the method's potential for synthesizing complex indazole derivatives, which hold significant promises for applications in pharmaceutical development and advanced materials research.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in Radical Hydrofunctionalization of Alkenes and Dienes via Reductive Metal‐Hydride Hydrogen Atom Transfer (MHAT)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The reductive metal‐hydride hydrogen atom transfer (MHAT) strategy has opened new avenues in organic synthesis. By leveraging the reductive generation of metal hydride species, particularly Co(III)‐H, this approach facilitates the addition of hydrogen and various functional groups to alkenes under milder conditions. Crucially, it avoids the need for stoichiometric amounts of oxidants and hydride donors, allowing for a wide range of transformations.
Abstract The metal‐hydride hydrogen atom transfer strategy (MHAT) has emerged as a robust approach for the radical hydrofunctionalization of alkenes, demonstrating exceptional functional group tolerance and chemoselectivity. Traditional methods for generating metal‐hydride (M‐H) species typically require oxidative conditions that depend on stoichiometric oxidants and hydride donors, posing challenges to sustainability and scalability. In contrast, the reductive MHAT strategy, which forms M‐H species through the transfer of a proton and an electron, offers a more concise and sustainable pathway for radical alkene hydrofunctionalization. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the key advances in reductive MHAT catalysis, highlighting recent innovations and discussing potential future directions for the field.
item.content:encoded:
The reductive metal-hydride hydrogen atom transfer (MHAT) strategy has opened new avenues in organic synthesis. By leveraging the reductive generation of metal hydride species, particularly Co(III)-H, this approach facilitates the addition of hydrogen and various functional groups to alkenes under milder conditions. Crucially, it avoids the need for stoichiometric amounts of oxidants and hydride donors, allowing for a wide range of transformations.


Abstract

The metal-hydride hydrogen atom transfer strategy (MHAT) has emerged as a robust approach for the radical hydrofunctionalization of alkenes, demonstrating exceptional functional group tolerance and chemoselectivity. Traditional methods for generating metal-hydride (M-H) species typically require oxidative conditions that depend on stoichiometric oxidants and hydride donors, posing challenges to sustainability and scalability. In contrast, the reductive MHAT strategy, which forms M-H species through the transfer of a proton and an electron, offers a more concise and sustainable pathway for radical alkene hydrofunctionalization. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the key advances in reductive MHAT catalysis, highlighting recent innovations and discussing potential future directions for the field.

item.dc:title: Recent Advances in Radical Hydrofunctionalization of Alkenes and Dienes via Reductive Metal‐Hydride Hydrogen Atom Transfer (MHAT)

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Monomers with Spirocyclic Acetal Units for Synthesis of Sustainable and Recyclable Polymers with Improved Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The recent progress on the molecular design and synthesis of functional monomers with spirocyclic acetal structures, particularly bio‐based ones, is highlighted and their use for preparation of high‐Tg polymers is discussed. The impact of the spirocyclic acetal structures on the properties and possibilities for chemical recycling of the resulting polymers are briefly summarized
Multi‐functional molecules with spirocyclic acetal structures are emerging as attractive monomers to prepare high‐performance polymers designed to be depolymerized and recycled under specific physicochemical conditions. Spirocyclic acetal structures are formed by condensation of a suitable aldehyde or ketone with a polyol so that the functionalities necessary for the polymerization are retained. In general, rigid spirocyclic acetal units can efficiently enhance the glass transition temperature (Tg) of the polymer. This typically increases, for example, the stiffness and use‐temperature of the materials. Furthermore, the inherent sensitivity of spirocyclic acetal units to acidic conditions may be utilized to develop polymers that may be conveniently and selectively cleaved into, for example, monomers or oligomers under controlled acidic conditions. This opens up opportunities for producing new chemically recyclable polymers and plastics. Herein, the recent progress in molecular design and synthesis of functional monomers with spirocyclic acetal structures and their use for the design and preparation of chemically recyclable high‐Tg polymers is highlighted. Monomers and polymers with the potential to be derived from sustainable bio‐based resources are given special attention.
item.content:encoded:
The recent progress on the molecular design and synthesis of functional monomers with spirocyclic acetal structures, particularly bio-based ones, is highlighted and their use for preparation of high-T g polymers is discussed. The impact of the spirocyclic acetal structures on the properties and possibilities for chemical recycling of the resulting polymers are briefly summarized


Multi-functional molecules with spirocyclic acetal structures are emerging as attractive monomers to prepare high-performance polymers designed to be depolymerized and recycled under specific physicochemical conditions. Spirocyclic acetal structures are formed by condensation of a suitable aldehyde or ketone with a polyol so that the functionalities necessary for the polymerization are retained. In general, rigid spirocyclic acetal units can efficiently enhance the glass transition temperature (T g) of the polymer. This typically increases, for example, the stiffness and use-temperature of the materials. Furthermore, the inherent sensitivity of spirocyclic acetal units to acidic conditions may be utilized to develop polymers that may be conveniently and selectively cleaved into, for example, monomers or oligomers under controlled acidic conditions. This opens up opportunities for producing new chemically recyclable polymers and plastics. Herein, the recent progress in molecular design and synthesis of functional monomers with spirocyclic acetal structures and their use for the design and preparation of chemically recyclable high-T g polymers is highlighted. Monomers and polymers with the potential to be derived from sustainable bio-based resources are given special attention.

item.dc:title: Monomers with Spirocyclic Acetal Units for Synthesis of Sustainable and Recyclable Polymers with Improved Properties

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoredox Catalytic Two‐Component Radical β‐Fluoro‐Fluorosulfonamidation Reaction of Styrenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: In this study, a visible‐light‐mediated two‐component β‐fluoro‐fluorosulfonamidation reaction of styrenes has been demonstrated. The bench‐stable reagent, N‐fluorosulfamoyl‐pyridinium tetrafluoroborate (FSAP) can be used as a photoredox‐active nitrogen‐centered radical precursor and also as the fluoride source. This transformation could convert a series of styrenes to functional group‐enriched products, including substrates with electron‐donating or withdrawing groups, as well as di‐ and tri‐substituents on the C‐C double bond.

This transformation could convert a series of styrenes to functional group-enriched products, including substrates with electron-donating or withdrawing groups, as well as di- and tri-substituents on the C-C double bond.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Latent Ruthenium Complexes Supported by Two N‐Heterocyclic Carbene Ligands: Synthesis and Catalytic Activity with Distinctive Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Novel bis‐N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ruthenium complexes were synthesized and tested as latent olefin metathesis catalysts. Catalysts containing a diisopropylphenyl substituent on the NHC were thermally activated at relatively low temperatures compared to catalysts with mesitylene substituents. Complexes with mixed saturated/unsaturated NHCs excelled in high‐temperature reactions with challenging substrates. UV‐C light activation was successful with complexes with benzylidene ligands exclusively.
Novel bis(N‐heterocyclic carbene [NHC]) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N‐heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR’ denotes Ph‐indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) are prepared from second‐ and third‐generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibit thermal latency in ring‐closing metathesis (RCM), cross‐metathesis (CM), and several ring‐opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions. Upon UV‐C (255 nm) irradiation, two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands prove to be highly effective for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene. The most active species incorporate IPr or SIPr as at least one NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Beyond their utility in UV‐C‐initiated ROMP, these complexes show promising activity for high‐temperature CM and RCM of alkenyl‐nitrile substrates.
item.content:encoded:
Novel bis-N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ruthenium complexes were synthesized and tested as latent olefin metathesis catalysts. Catalysts containing a diisopropylphenyl substituent on the NHC were thermally activated at relatively low temperatures compared to catalysts with mesitylene substituents. Complexes with mixed saturated/unsaturated NHCs excelled in high-temperature reactions with challenging substrates. UV-C light activation was successful with complexes with benzylidene ligands exclusively.


Novel bis(N-heterocyclic carbene [NHC]) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N-heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR’ denotes Ph-indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) are prepared from second- and third-generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibit thermal latency in ring-closing metathesis (RCM), cross-metathesis (CM), and several ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions. Upon UV-C (255 nm) irradiation, two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands prove to be highly effective for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene. The most active species incorporate IPr or SIPr as at least one NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Beyond their utility in UV-C-initiated ROMP, these complexes show promising activity for high-temperature CM and RCM of alkenyl-nitrile substrates.

item.title: Heteroatom‐Functionalized λ5‐Phosphinines—Synthesis and Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
λ5‐Phosphinines with a S‐, P‐, N‐, and B‐substituent at the C‐4 position are synthesized by several newly developed procedures. Heteroatom‐functionalized phosphinines exhibit highly effective emission with variable and tunable wavelengths according to the substituent function. Redox, complexation, and the reaction of the functional group cause changing their fluorescence.
λ5‐Phosphinines with a heteroatom functionality at the C‐4 position are synthesized by several newly developed procedures. S‐, P‐, N‐, and B‐substituted phosphinines exhibit highly effective emission with variable and tunable wavelength according to the substituent electronic density. Photophysical properties with demonstrative examples of qualitative fluorescent detection are also reported

Redox, complexation, and the reaction of the functional group cause changing their fluorescence.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mechanochemical Synthesis of 5‐Amino‐4‐Cyanoxazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A mechanochemical protocol enables the rapid synthesis of 5‐amino‐4‐cyanoxazoles from 2‐amido‐3,3‐dichloroacrylonitriles and aliphatic amines in the presence of dipotassium phosphate. The method achieves high yields within minutes under solvent‐minimized conditions, offering improved sustainability for the construction of oxazole scaffolds.
A mechanochemical methodology for the preparation of 5‐amino‐4‐cyanoxazoles through the reaction of 2‐amido‐3,3‐dichloroacrylonitriles with primary or secondary aliphatic amines (or their respective salts) in the presence of dipotassium phosphate is reported. The process is carried out by processing the mixture of starting materials in a mixer mill, with ethanol used as a liquid‐assisted grinding additive. Dipotassium phosphate serves as a cost‐efficient and non‐toxic inorganic base, ensuring 100% carbon economy of the process. The reaction produces the corresponding oxazole products with up to 97% yield in just 10 min. However, preparative scope of the method is restricted to highly nucleophilic and sterically unobstructed primary and secondary aliphatic amines. Aromatic amines display low reactivity at room temperature. For instance, indoline achieves only 43% conversion to its oxazole product after 3 h.
item.content:encoded:
A mechanochemical protocol enables the rapid synthesis of 5-amino-4-cyanoxazoles from 2-amido-3,3-dichloroacrylonitriles and aliphatic amines in the presence of dipotassium phosphate. The method achieves high yields within minutes under solvent-minimized conditions, offering improved sustainability for the construction of oxazole scaffolds.


A mechanochemical methodology for the preparation of 5-amino-4-cyanoxazoles through the reaction of 2-amido-3,3-dichloroacrylonitriles with primary or secondary aliphatic amines (or their respective salts) in the presence of dipotassium phosphate is reported. The process is carried out by processing the mixture of starting materials in a mixer mill, with ethanol used as a liquid-assisted grinding additive. Dipotassium phosphate serves as a cost-efficient and non-toxic inorganic base, ensuring 100% carbon economy of the process. The reaction produces the corresponding oxazole products with up to 97% yield in just 10 min. However, preparative scope of the method is restricted to highly nucleophilic and sterically unobstructed primary and secondary aliphatic amines. Aromatic amines display low reactivity at room temperature. For instance, indoline achieves only 43% conversion to its oxazole product after 3 h.

item.title: Structural Determination and Characterization of Electronic Properties of Photosilylated Derivatives of C70
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The photoreactions of C70 and mesityl‐substituted disilirane (disilacyclopropane) 1a afforded the corresponding adducts 2a and 3a, the former of which was reported previously. The structures of 2a and 3a were unequivocally established respectively as a 1,4‐adduct structure at the [d,d'] site and as a 1,2‐adduct at the [a,b] bond, respectively, using single‐crystal X‐ray crystallographic analyses. The latter structure represents the first example of crystallographic study of 1,3‐disilolane (1,3‐disilacyclopentane) derivatives of fullerenes. The electronic properties of these products are characterized based on electrochemical and theoretical studies elucidating the electron‐donating effects of silyl groups.
item.content:encoded: The photoreactions of C70 and mesityl-substituted disilirane (disilacyclopropane) 1a afforded the corresponding adducts 2a and 3a, the former of which was reported previously. The structures of 2a and 3a were unequivocally established respectively as a 1,4-adduct structure at the [d,d'] site and as a 1,2-adduct at the [a,b] bond, respectively, using single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analyses. The latter structure represents the first example of crystallographic study of 1,3-disilolane (1,3-disilacyclopentane) derivatives of fullerenes. The electronic properties of these products are characterized based on electrochemical and theoretical studies elucidating the electron-donating effects of silyl groups.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Improved Total Synthesis of Millepachine through a Negishi Acylative Cross‐Coupling Protocol
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The chalcone Millepachine exhibits interesting biological properties, such as cytotoxic and antitumor activity against various cancer cells. Despite these characteristics the only published synthesis gives the product in modest yield. A study on the acylative Negishi cross‐coupling for obtaining Millepachine in higher yield is presented. Both iodo‐ and bromo‐2H‐chromene derivatives, as precursors of the organozinc halides, were synthesized and different routes for obtaining the organometallic species were explored. The transmetalation from the aryllithium proved to be the most efficient method to obtain a reactive organozinc species for the Negishi cross‐ coupling with 4‐methoxycynnamoil chloride. Up to 75% yield of pure product was obtained corresponding to 43% overall yield from commercially available 3‐methoxyphenol.

Both iodo- and bromo-2H-chromene derivatives, as precursors of the organozinc halides, were synthesized and different routes for obtaining the organometallic species were explored. The transmetalation from the aryllithium proved to be the most efficient method to obtain a reactive organozinc species for the Negishi cross- coupling with 4-methoxycynnamoil chloride. item.title: Total Synthesis of Pegaharmine I Enabled by Visible‐Light Photocatalytic Nitrone Formation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The total synthesis of pegaharmine I is achieved through a three‐step process, featuring a key visible‐light photocatalyzed nitrone formation reaction. Single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction confirms the structure of the natural product. Additionally, a water‐promoted photocatalytic approach is developed, highlighting the potential of visible‐light photocatalysis for the efficient synthesis of natural products.
The first total synthesis of pegaharmine I is accomplished by a three‐step strategy featuring a visible‐light‐photocatalyzed nitrone formation reaction as the key step. The structure of this natural product is confirmed by crystallographic analysis. Water‐promoted photocatalysis, achieved by incorporating water into the reaction medium, has also been established.

Additionally, a water-promoted photocatalytic approach is developed, highlighting the potential of visible-light photocatalysis for the efficient synthesis of natural products.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Reactions of Halogermylenes with N‐Heterocyclic Carbenes: Selective Formation of Low Valent Ge(II) Species
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The reaction of halogermylenes with N‐heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) to form halogermylene mono‐NHC adducts and the germyliumylidene cation bis‐NHC adducts is explored. Structural analysis and density functional theory calculations reveal their polarized covalent GeC bonds and dynamic NHC ligand exchange.
The reactions of the Rind‐based 1,2‐dihalodigermenes, (Eind)BrGe=GeBr(Eind) (1a), and (EMind)ClGe=GeCl(EMind) (1b), with two types of N‐heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) (Im‐iPr2Me2 and Im‐Me4) result in the formation of the halogermylene mono‐NHC adducts, (Im‐iPr2Me2)(Eind)GeBr (2a') and (Im‐iPr2Me2)(EMind)GeCl (2b'), and the germyliumylidene cation bis‐NHC adducts, [(Im‐Me4)2(Eind)Ge]+[Br−] (3a) and [(Im‐Me4)2(EMind)Ge]+[Cl−] (3b). The resulting Ge(II) species are stabilized by the bulky Rind groups and the strongly σ‐donating NHC ligands, whose structures are confirmed by a single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction (SC‐XRD) analysis. Based on density functional theory (DFT) and quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) calculations of 2a’ and the cationic part of 3a, it is concluded that while the GeC(Eind) and GeC(NHC) bonds exhibit distinct differences in their degrees of polarization, all the GeC bonds display a partially polarized covalent character. Both reaction energy calculations and experimental studies suggested the potential liberation of an NHC ligand from the germyliumylidene cation bis‐NHC adducts, leading to the exchange of the NHC ligands. The formation mechanism of 3a from 1a and two NHC molecules via (Im‐Me4)(Eind)GeBr (2a) is discussed based on DFT calculations.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Earth‐Abundant Metal Complexes as Catalysts for the Dehydrogenative Coupling of Hydrosilanes and Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This concept article examines the potential of Earth‐abundant metal catalysts in the dehydrogenative coupling of hydrosilanes and alcohols, a key transformation for sustainable organosilicon synthesis and a promising method for hydrogen production. Recent advancements, mechanistic insights, and the implications of using them as viable alternatives to platinum group metals are discussed, including transition to greener and more cost‐effective catalytic processes.
The dehydrogenative coupling of hydrosilanes with alcohols or water is a fundamental transformation in organosilicon chemistry, enabling the synthesis of alkoxysilanes, silanols, and siloxanes—key materials for coatings and adhesives. Traditionally, these reactions have relied on catalysts based on platinum group metals, which are costly and scarce. The development of Earth‐abundant metal (EAM) catalysts offers a sustainable and cost‐effective alternative. This concept article highlights recent advancements in homogeneous EAM catalysis for these transformations, focusing on mechanistic insights, reactivity trends, and catalytic efficiencies. Catalysts based on manganese, iron, cobalt, copper, or zinc are reshaping the field by offering efficient and selective processes for the synthesis of alkoxysilanes, silanols, and siloxanes. Moreover, a key feature of these catalytic systems is their ability to generate dihydrogen as a byproduct, offering potential applications in hydrogen storage and utilization. Despite the good performances of EAM catalysts in the hydrolysis or alcoholysis of silanes, challenges remain, including improving turnover numbers, substrate scope, and catalyst stability. Future developments integrating computational and experimental approaches will be key to optimizing these systems.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Rhodium(II)‐Catalyzed Oxo‐Amination of Aryl Cyclopropanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: We describe a rhodium(II)‐catalyzed method for synthesizing β‐amino ketones from aryl cyclopropanes, utilizing water as an oxygen source and N‐fluorobis(benzenesulfonamide) (NFSI) as a commercially available nitrogen source. This approach offers good substrate tolerance under mild conditions, providing a novel and practical route for β‐amino ketone synthesis. Mechanistic studies reveal a sequential cascade pathway initiated by single electron transfer (SET) facilitated by the rhodium(II) catalyst, followed by hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) and radical polar crossover (RPC) steps. These insights underscore the potential of rhodium(II) in driving radical amination reactions, enhancing the synthesis of β‐amino ketones from simple precursors.
item.content:encoded: We describe a rhodium(II)-catalyzed method for synthesizing β-amino ketones from aryl cyclopropanes, utilizing water as an oxygen source and N-fluorobis(benzenesulfonamide) (NFSI) as a commercially available nitrogen source. This approach offers good substrate tolerance under mild conditions, providing a novel and practical route for β-amino ketone synthesis. Mechanistic studies reveal a sequential cascade pathway initiated by single electron transfer (SET) facilitated by the rhodium(II) catalyst, followed by hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) and radical polar crossover (RPC) steps. These insights underscore the potential of rhodium(II) in driving radical amination reactions, enhancing the synthesis of β-amino ketones from simple precursors.

item.title: Formation of Prenylated Pterocarpans from Synthetically Derived Demethylmedicarpin by Regioselective Gold(I)‐Catalyzed Intramolecular Hydroarylation and Related Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Three prenylated pterocarpans including erybraedin A and erybraedin C have been synthesised from (±)‐demethylmedicarpin, itself prepared in four simple steps starting from resorcinol and 2,4‐dimethoxyphenylacetic acid. A gold(I)‐catalyzed and two‐fold intramolecular hydroarylation (IMHA) reaction of a readily‐derived bis‐propargyl ether of (±)‐demethylmedicarpin proceeds with remarkable regio‐selectivity to afford the racemate of a recently reported but yet‐to‐be named bis‐2H‐chromene‐annulated pterocarpan‐containing natural product. A possible explanation for this potentially very useful selectivity is advanced. In a related reaction sequence, a readily‐derived bis‐allyl ether of (±)‐demethylmedicarpin undergoes a thermally‐induced and two‐fold aromatic Claisen rearrangement (ACR) to give a 1:5 mixture of the racemic modifications of the isomeric and cytotoxic natural products erybraedin A and erybraedin C.

A possible explanation for this potentially very useful selectivity is advanced. In a related reaction sequence, a readily-derived bis-allyl ether of (±)-demethylmedicarpin undergoes a thermally-induced and two-fold aromatic Claisen rearrangement (ACR) to give a 1:5 mixture of the racemic modifications of the isomeric and cytotoxic natural products erybraedin A and erybraedin C.

item.title: N‐Heterocyclic‐Carbene‐Catalyzed Asymmetric Cyclization of Cyclohexadienone‐Tethered Ynals to Stereodivergent 6,5‐Bicyclic and 6,5,5‐Tricyclic Products
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Transforming a prochiral substrate into two stereodivergent products using a single chiral catalyst remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report an NHC‐catalyzed asymmetric cyclization of cyclohexadienone‐tethered ynals, enabling the preparation of two stereodivergent products: 6,5‐bicyclic and 6,5,5‐tricyclic frameworks. The reaction proceeds through two distinct pathways: an allenolate‐Michael addition/esterification sequence and an allenolate‐Michael addition/intramolecular Dieckmann condensation process. This approach represents a novel and efficient strategy for transforming a prochiral substrate into two products in a stereodivergent manner.
item.content:encoded: Transforming a prochiral substrate into two stereodivergent products using a single chiral catalyst remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report an NHC-catalyzed asymmetric cyclization of cyclohexadienone-tethered ynals, enabling the preparation of two stereodivergent products: 6,5-bicyclic and 6,5,5-tricyclic frameworks. The reaction proceeds through two distinct pathways: an allenolate-Michael addition/esterification sequence and an allenolate-Michael addition/intramolecular Dieckmann condensation process. This approach represents a novel and efficient strategy for transforming a prochiral substrate into two products in a stereodivergent manner.

item.dc:title: N‐Heterocyclic‐Carbene‐Catalyzed Asymmetric Cyclization of Cyclohexadienone‐Tethered Ynals to Stereodivergent 6,5‐Bicyclic and 6,5,5‐Tricyclic Products

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Exploring Self‐Assembly and Viscoelastic Behavior of Pyrene‐Based Fluorescent Hydrogel: Designing Paper Sensors for Water‐Soluble Explosives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Self‐assembly properties and viscoelastic behavior of pyrene‐based fluorescent hydrogel has been developed for the detection of water‐Soluble explosives and also paper strips designed for on‐location analysis purpose
Abstract Recently organic‐doped polyethyleneimine based hydrogels have emerged as smart responsive materials for optical sensing applications. To this end, herein we have designed and synthesized a biocompatible fluorescent hydrogel based on polyethyleneimine (PEI), incorporating pyrene as the polyaromatic signaling moiety. The self‐assembly properties of the composite materials were primarily influenced by the nature of the organic dopant, the degree of substitution, and the microenvironment. The presence of the polyaromatic scaffold, such as pyrene, not only affects the fluorescence properties of the molecules but also modulates the extent of cross‐linking by controlling π‐π stacking interactions. The hydrogel formation was observed in a methanol‐water (3 % v/v) mixture. Additionally, the pyrene‐attached hydrogel demonstrated promising potential for the highly sensitive detection of trinitrophenol (TNP), a toxic, water‐soluble explosive. Spectroscopic investigations revealed that the electrostatic interaction between the ammonium units of PYR‐PEI and picrate anions in aqueous medium facilitated charge transfer from pyrene to the picrate anion, resulting in a fluorescence turn‐off response. Along with fluorometric response, using rheological experiments we show that the viscoelastic behaviour of the polymer gels also varied significantly upon addition of TNP. To determine the viscoelastic parameters, a two‐term Maxwell model was used to fit the angular frequency‐dependent storage and loss moduli measurements. Additionally, hydrogel‐coated, highly robust, and reusable paper strips were also developed for on‐field detection of TNP.

Spectroscopic investigations revealed that the electrostatic interaction between the ammonium units of PYR-PEI and picrate anions in aqueous medium facilitated charge transfer from pyrene to the picrate anion, resulting in a fluorescence turn-off response. Along with fluorometric response, using rheological experiments we show that the viscoelastic behaviour of the polymer gels also varied significantly upon addition of TNP. Additionally, hydrogel-coated, highly robust, and reusable paper strips were also developed for on-field detection of TNP.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Tandem Friedel‐Crafts Alkylation/Lactonization for γ‐Lactone
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In this study, we present a tandem Friedel‐Crafts Alkylation/Lactonization reaction using aromatic compounds and cyclo‐anhydrides as raw materials to obtain γ‐lactones under metal‐free conditions. This method offers operational simplicity, broad substrate scope, and high synthetic efficiency. Furthermore, the gram scale experiment and the synthesis of natural product Cytosporanone A were achieved using this method.
Abstract The lactonization of C(sp3)−H bonds from simple, readily available materials remains a significant challenge in organic synthesis. In this study, we present a tandem Friedel‐Crafts Alkylation /Lactonization reaction using aromatic compounds and cyclo‐anhydrides as raw materials to obtain γ‐lactones under metal‐free conditions. This method offers operational simplicity, broad substrate scope, and high synthetic efficiency. Furthermore, the gram scale experiment of this reaction had been conducted, and the synthesis of natural product Cytosporanone A was achieved using this method.

Furthermore, the gram scale experiment and the synthesis of natural product Cytosporanone A were achieved using this method.


Abstract

The lactonization of C(sp3)−H bonds from simple, readily available materials remains a significant challenge in organic synthesis. In this study, we present a tandem Friedel-Crafts Alkylation /Lactonization reaction using aromatic compounds and cyclo-anhydrides as raw materials to obtain γ-lactones under metal-free conditions. This method offers operational simplicity, broad substrate scope, and high synthetic efficiency. Furthermore, the gram scale experiment of this reaction had been conducted, and the synthesis of natural product Cytosporanone A was achieved using this method.

item.title: Acid‐Promoted Structural Reorganization of Pull–Pull Alkylidenecyclobutanes: A Cascade Synthesis of Three‐Substituted γ‐Butyrolactones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An unprecedented acid‐promoted skeletal reorganization process of pull–pull alkylidenecyclobutanes is discovered. This transformation provides an efficient synthetic route to functionalized three‐substituted γ‐butyrolactones in moderate‐to‐high yields.
An unprecedented acid‐promoted structural reorganization of pull–pull alkylidenecyclobutanes into three‐substituted γ‐butyrolactones, in moderate‐to‐high yields, via a ring closure‐ring contraction followed by intramolecular ring‐opening cyclization is described.

An unprecedented acid-promoted structural reorganization of pull–pull alkylidenecyclobutanes into three-substituted γ-butyrolactones, in moderate-to-high yields, via a ring closure-ring contraction followed by intramolecular ring-opening cyclization is described.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Chromium(II)‐Catalyzed Stereoselective Cross‐Electrophile Coupling of Geminal Difluoroalkenes with Aliphatic Halides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The cross‐electrophile coupling of geminal difluoroalkenes with alkyl halides is catalyzed by low‐cost CrCl2 combining with dtbpy ligand. It provides a viable strategy to stereoselectively form alkylated Z‐fluoroalkenes, achieving the compatibility to a wide range of functionalities such as iodide, bromide, chloride, cyano, amino, and ester.
Herein, an effective, mild, and practical approach to stereoselective cross‐electrophile coupling of difluoroalkenes with alkyl halides by cost‐effective chromium catalysis is reported. This reaction is promoted by inexpensive CrCl2 combining with bipyridine ligand and manganese as the reductant, enabling the achievement of the reductive coupling of geminal difluoroalkenes with primary, secondary, and tertiary alkyl halides at ambient temperature. It provides a valuable and scalable approach to form tri‐substituted Z‐fluoroalkylalkenes with good compatibility with a range of important functional groups. Preliminary mechanistic studies indicate that the coupling reaction is initiated by forming alkyl radical by addition to alkene and combining with Cr(II) or by coordination with Cr(II) and carbometallation of difluoroalkenes in giving (alkyl)Cr species, which converts to Z‐alkylated fluoroalkene motifs in a stereoselective manner by elimination of β‐fluoride atoms.
item.content:encoded:
The cross-electrophile coupling of geminal difluoroalkenes with alkyl halides is catalyzed by low-cost CrCl2 combining with dtbpy ligand. It provides a viable strategy to stereoselectively form alkylated Z-fluoroalkenes, achieving the compatibility to a wide range of functionalities such as iodide, bromide, chloride, cyano, amino, and ester.


Herein, an effective, mild, and practical approach to stereoselective cross-electrophile coupling of difluoroalkenes with alkyl halides by cost-effective chromium catalysis is reported. This reaction is promoted by inexpensive CrCl2 combining with bipyridine ligand and manganese as the reductant, enabling the achievement of the reductive coupling of geminal difluoroalkenes with primary, secondary, and tertiary alkyl halides at ambient temperature. It provides a valuable and scalable approach to form tri-substituted Z-fluoroalkylalkenes with good compatibility with a range of important functional groups. Preliminary mechanistic studies indicate that the coupling reaction is initiated by forming alkyl radical by addition to alkene and combining with Cr(II) or by coordination with Cr(II) and carbometallation of difluoroalkenes in giving (alkyl)Cr species, which converts to Z-alkylated fluoroalkene motifs in a stereoselective manner by elimination of β-fluoride atoms.
item.dc:creator: Yunqian Hou, Xiaoming Zeng
item.dc:title: Chromium(II)‐Catalyzed Stereoselective Cross‐Electrophile Coupling of Geminal Difluoroalkenes with Aliphatic Halides

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Harnessing Electricity in Dehydrogenative Coupling: Transition Metal‐Free Synthesis of Quinoline Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Providing easy access to quinoline derivatives under room temperature, transition metal‐free, and oxidant‐free conditions using electricity as an oxidant through a dehydrogenative pathway. A wide range of functional groups are tolerated, giving the desired quinoline product in good yields.
An efficient strategy is demonstrated for the electrocatalytic synthesis of 2‐aryl quinoline derivatives via an anodic dehydrogenation of 2‐aminobenzyl alcohol molecules followed by condensation with carbonyl compounds at room temperature. The current protocol requires only electricity as the green oxidant, provides the desired products in good to excellent yield, and is compatible with a wide range of functional groups.

item.title: Nickel(II)‐Catalyzed Oxidative Homocoupling of Terminal Alkynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A catalytic system for the homocoupling reactions of various terminal alkynes has been developed. This reaction is characterized by cheap and stable NiCl2 as catalyst, 1,10‐phenanthroline as the ligand, air as the oxidant, mild reaction conditions, and excellent functional group compatibility, demonstrating great potential for practical applications in the construction of symmetric 1,3‐diyne derivatives.
The homocoupling of terminal alkynes is a key approach for constructing 1,3‐diynes, typically relying on copper‐based bimetallic systems. Herein, a catalytic system is developed based on nickel chloride, using 1,10‐phenanthroline as the ligand and air as the oxidant, which successfully enables the homocoupling reactions of various terminal alkynes. This reaction is characterized by cheap and stable NiCl2 as catalyst, mild reaction conditions, and excellent functional group compatibility, demonstrating great potential for practical applications.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Amphiphilic Fluoro‐Functionalized Cellulosic Materials: Synthesis, Characterization, and Organic Dye Adsorption Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
New amphiphilic fluoro‐functionalized cellulosic materials are being yielded through nucleophilic aromatic substitution. Covalent attachment of fluorinated moiety into biopolymers is being assured with full characterization. Fluoro‐functionalized materials are being incorporated in alginate beads to remove organic pollutants from wastewater. Functionalization is leading to a three‐ to eightfold increase in the dye‐removal efficiency, the resulting functionalized‐beads can be also easily recycled .
The growing interest toward biopolymers application in amphiphilic conditions prompts one to explore the preparation of fluorinated cellulosic materials. Cellulose (CE) and carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) are functionalized with highly fluorinated pendants, through a nucleophilic aromatic substitution on 3‐pentadecafluoroheptyl‐5‐pentafluorophenyl‐1,2,4‐oxadiazole (FOX) leading to the corresponding fluorinated biopolymers CE‐FOX and CMC‐FOX. Structural and thermal stability confirm covalent attachment of the fluorinated moiety onto the cellulosic skeleton and highlighted an interesting 2D texture of the CMC‐FOX material. Hybrid and amphiphilic features of CE‐FOX and CMC‐FOX, are confirmed by water and oil contact angle measurements. Applications as adsorbent material for organic contaminants from an aqueous solution are tested by previously incorporating the functional biopolymer into sodium alginate (SA) hydrogel beads. Rhodamine B (RhB) is used as a model wastewater pollutant. Fluoro‐functionalization led to a three‐ to eightfold increase in the dye‐removal efficiency of the SA‐incorporated biopolymer with respect to the corresponding non‐fluorinated material (from 11% to 48% for SA/CE vs SA/CE‐FOX beads and from 11% to 94% for SA/CMC vs SA/CMC‐FOX beads). Recyclability tests show good residual performance of SA/CMC‐FOX beads after seven desorption/reuse cycles opening the way to more sustainable adsorbing processes for the removal of emerging pollutants from contaminated water.
item.content:encoded:

Functionalization is leading to a three- to eightfold increase in the dye-removal efficiency, the resulting functionalized-beads can be also easily recycled .

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Pd‐Catalyzed Vicinal Difunctionalization of Carboranes with Benzoxazoles, Indoles, and Anilines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In the article, a Pd‐catalyzed cross‐coupling reaction has been developed to incorporate benzoxazoles into m‐carborane structures without preactivation using alkyllithium reagents. Subsequent regioselective iodination and the second cross couplings with various NH heterocycles and anilines yield the desired difunctionalized products. Challenging substrates such as heteroanilines and benzamide are also tolerated under the developed condition.
Icosahedral carboranes have a wide range of applications in medicinal chemistry, material science, and catalysis. Although various methods have been disclosed for functionalizing carborane structures, the methods to incorporate different types of heterocycles are still lacking. This limitation is likely due to the functional group incompatibility under previously reported reaction conditions. In this article, a streamlined protocol is presented to prepare a new class of vicinal difunctionalized carboranes containing benzoxazoles, NH heterocycles, and anilines. This method involves a direct cross‐coupling between 9‐bromo‐m‐carborane and benzoxazoles, thereby eliminating the necessity for preceding deprotonation of the acidic C2 proton present in benzoxazole. Subsequent regioselective iodination at the B(10) vertex of the carborane and the second cross‐coupling reactions with diverse indoles and anilines result in the formation of the desired vicinal difunctionalized products.
item.content:encoded:

Subsequent regioselective iodination and the second cross couplings with various NH heterocycles and anilines yield the desired difunctionalized products. Challenging substrates such as heteroanilines and benzamide are also tolerated under the developed condition.

item.title: Recent Advances in the Formation and Transformation of Propargyl Radical
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Propargyl radical is a very important free radical in organic synthesis. The tautomerization with the allenyl radical enables the diverse reactivities, and then propargyl compounds and allenes can be obtained. Because of its properties, how to control the chemical selectivity and enantioselectivity is the key in the radical propargyl functionalization. In this review, the reactions involving propargyl radicals in recent years were summarized according to the means for the production of propargyl radicals, different reaction types and asymmetric catalytic transformations.

item.title: Gold(I)‐Catalyzed Allylation and Tandem Allylation–Cycloisomerization of Stannylated Propargyl Acetates with Allylsilanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes, synthesized by the cycloisomerization of 1,5‐enynes, serve as key scaffolds in various natural products. Gold(I)‐catalyzed cycloisomerization of 1,5‐enynes is an efficient route to bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes. However, gold(I)‐catalyzed 1,5‐enyne synthesis, particularly with a terminal alkyne, has not yet been fully explored. This study presents a mild and general method for the gold(I)‐catalyzed allylation and tandem allylation–cycloisomerization of stannylated propargyl acetates with allylsilanes, yielding 1,5‐enynes with terminal alkyne moiety and bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes. The catalytic system ((4‐MeOC6H4)3PAuCl/AgSbF6) enabled the efficient synthesis of 1,5‐enynes with good to high yields and regioselectivities. In addition, gold(I)‐catalyzed tandem allylation–cycloisomerization using (JohnPhos)Au(MeCN)SbF6 afforded bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes with high regiocontrol. Stannylated propargyl acetates proved crucial in enhancing selectivity for both product classes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multigram Synthesis of 3‐Azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane Derivatives Including Bicyclic Thalidomide Analogs
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Bicyclic Compounds: An efficient approach to the multigram preparation of 1‐amino‐3‐azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane‐2,4‐dione – a valuable building block for drug discovery – was developed. The method included only four steps and allowed for the preparation of the key compound in 48 % overall yield on up to 30 g scale. It was used synthesize monoprotected bicyclic diamines and a series of bridged Thalidomide analogs.
Abstract An efficient approach to the multigram synthesis of 3‐azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptanes is described. The method relied on the intramolecular imide formation in the properly 1,3‐functionalized cyclobutane derivative. In turn, the latter compound was obtained via the diastereoselective Strecker reaction of readily accessible 3‐oxocyclobutanecarboxylate. The resulting synthetic intermediate – 1‐amino‐3‐azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane‐2,4‐dione – was used to synthesize several monoprotected bicyclic diamines valuable as building blocks for medicinal chemistry, as well as a series of bridged analogs of Thalidomide, a known anticancer drug and a component of proteolysis‐targeting chimeras (PROTACs).
item.content:encoded:
Bicyclic Compounds: An efficient approach to the multigram preparation of 1-amino-3-azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane-2,4-dione – a valuable building block for drug discovery – was developed. The method included only four steps and allowed for the preparation of the key compound in 48 % overall yield on up to 30 g scale. It was used synthesize monoprotected bicyclic diamines and a series of bridged Thalidomide analogs.


Abstract

An efficient approach to the multigram synthesis of 3-azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptanes is described. The method relied on the intramolecular imide formation in the properly 1,3-functionalized cyclobutane derivative. In turn, the latter compound was obtained via the diastereoselective Strecker reaction of readily accessible 3-oxocyclobutanecarboxylate. The resulting synthetic intermediate – 1-amino-3-azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane-2,4-dione – was used to synthesize several monoprotected bicyclic diamines valuable as building blocks for medicinal chemistry, as well as a series of bridged analogs of Thalidomide, a known anticancer drug and a component of proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs).

item.dc:title: Multigram Synthesis of 3‐Azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane Derivatives Including Bicyclic Thalidomide Analogs

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in Transition Metal‐Free Strategies for the Transformation of Amides into Carbonyl Compounds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Amides are fundamental functional groups in organic synthesis and play crucial roles in medicinal chemistry and material science. Traditionally, amide transformations have often relied on transition‐metal catalysts; however, recent advances have demonstrated efficient transition‐metal‐free strategies for amide bond activation. This review provides a comprehensive overview of emerging methodologies that enable selective formation of C–N, C–C, C–O, C–H, and C–X bonds. Key developments that offer sustainable and practical alternatives to conventional approaches include borate‐ and boronic acid‐mediated transamidations, phosphoric acid‐promoted transformations, and radical‐based strategies. Additionally, nucleophilic substitutions with carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen‐based nucleophiles have expanded the synthetic utility of amides by yielding diverse carbonyl and heterocyclic compounds. Mechanistic insights into these transformations reveal the role of electronic and steric effects in amide reactivity. By categorizing these methodologies based on amide substrates and reaction pathways, this review aims to provide a valuable resource for researchers seeking efficient, metal‐free strategies for amide bond manipulation.
item.content:encoded: Amides are fundamental functional groups in organic synthesis and play crucial roles in medicinal chemistry and material science. Traditionally, amide transformations have often relied on transition-metal catalysts; however, recent advances have demonstrated efficient transition-metal-free strategies for amide bond activation. This review provides a comprehensive overview of emerging methodologies that enable selective formation of C–N, C–C, C–O, C–H, and C–X bonds. Key developments that offer sustainable and practical alternatives to conventional approaches include borate- and boronic acid-mediated transamidations, phosphoric acid-promoted transformations, and radical-based strategies. Additionally, nucleophilic substitutions with carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen-based nucleophiles have expanded the synthetic utility of amides by yielding diverse carbonyl and heterocyclic compounds. Mechanistic insights into these transformations reveal the role of electronic and steric effects in amide reactivity. By categorizing these methodologies based on amide substrates and reaction pathways, this review aims to provide a valuable resource for researchers seeking efficient, metal-free strategies for amide bond manipulation.
item.dc:creator: Karthik Rajan Rajamanickam, Robin Prakash Sirvin Rajan, Nithin Pootheri, Chin-Fa Lee, Sunwoo Lee
item.dc:title: Recent Advances in Transition Metal‐Free Strategies for the Transformation of Amides into Carbonyl Compounds

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Diazo compounds under visible light: Stereoselective synthesis of cyclic architectures
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Diazo compounds are versatile and valuable reagents in organic synthesis. The reaction of diazo substrates under photochemical conditions find high selectivity compared to that under thermal conditions. In the presence of light, they can act as carbene precursors or radical sources depending upon the reaction conditions and catalysts used. Recent years have witnessed a great advancement in visible‐light‐induced photochemistry of diazo compounds for asymmetric access to various cyclic compounds. In this review, we summarized recent advances (2020‐2024) in stereoselective synthesis of cyclic scaffolds via visible‐light irradiation of diazo compounds. This review is organized according to the ring size of the synthesized compounds, viz., three, four, five, six, seven and higher membered ring systems. With an emphasis of mechanistic insights and scope of the reactions, this review shades light on current trends in this emerging field.

item.title: DBU‐Mediated [4+2] Cyclization of Sulfoxonium Ylides and o‐Phenylenediamines for Quinoxaline Synthesis
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Herein, a novel DBU (1,8‐Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‐7‐ene) mediates the synthesis of quinoxalines from o‐phenylenediamines and sulfoxonium ylides. The method requires no metal catalysts and oxidizers, is economical and environmentally friendly, and has superior functional group tolerance. Mechanistic studies have shown that DBU proceeds by inducing reactions through nucleophilic attack on sulfoxonium ylides. Gram‐scale synthesis and various cross‐reactions further demonstrate the merits of this strategy.
Abstract A novel method for the synthesis of quinoxalines from o‐phenylenediamines and sulfoxonium ylides, mediated by DBU (1,8‐Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‐7‐ene), is presented. This method does not require metal catalysts or oxidants, making it economical and environmentally friendly, while exhibiting excellent functional group tolerance. Mechanistic studies suggest that DBU facilitates the reaction through nucleophilic attack on sulfoxonium ylides. Gram‐scale synthesis and various cross‐reactions further highlight the advantages of this strategy.

Abstract

A novel method for the synthesis of quinoxalines from o-phenylenediamines and sulfoxonium ylides, mediated by DBU (1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene), is presented. This method does not require metal catalysts or oxidants, making it economical and environmentally friendly, while exhibiting excellent functional group tolerance. Mechanistic studies suggest that DBU facilitates the reaction through nucleophilic attack on sulfoxonium ylides. Gram-scale synthesis and various cross-reactions further highlight the advantages of this strategy.

item.title: Synthesis of C2‐Silylated Indoles and Indolines Enabled by Iridium‐Catalyzed Silylation of Indolines with Hydrosilanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An iridium‐catalyzed one‐pot reaction of indolines and hydrosilanes is presented to access C2‐silylated indoles. Additionally, a rare example of iridium‐catalyzed direct C2‐selective C(sp3)–H silylation of indolines has also been established.
An efficient iridium‐catalyzed one‐pot protocol is reported for the synthesis of C2‐silylated indoles from indolines and hydrosilanes. Mechanistic investigations suggest that the transformation proceeds through a tandem dehydrogenation/C–H silylation pathway. Furthermore, an example of iridium‐catalyzed direct C2‐selective C(sp3)–H silylation of indolines is also disclosed.

An efficient iridium-catalyzed one-pot protocol is reported for the synthesis of C2-silylated indoles from indolines and hydrosilanes. Mechanistic investigations suggest that the transformation proceeds through a tandem dehydrogenation/C–H silylation pathway. Furthermore, an example of iridium-catalyzed direct C2-selective C(sp 3)–H silylation of indolines is also disclosed.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Chemo‐ and Regio‐selective Dual‐Functionalization of Arenes: Synthesis of Multi‐Functional Aromatics via Aromaticity Destruction‐Reconstruction Process
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Dual functionalization of arenes via a dearomatization‐functionalization‐rearomatization strategy facilitates chemo‐ and regioselective functionalization on phenols or anilines. This strategy proceeds via 2,5‐cyclohexadienones and 2,5‐cyclohexadienimines intermediates and permits a wide range of functionalizations with various coupling partners, enabling rapid molecular diversification under sustainable and transition metal‐free conditions.
Abstract Dual functionalizations of arenes promise to remain a powerful and versatile strategy for the synthesis of complex molecules with diverse applications in various fields. Dearomatization‐Functionalization‐rearomatization strategy emerges as a versatile tool for chemo‐ and regioselective functionalization of arenes via 2,5‐cyclohexadienone/2,5‐cyclohexadienimines, which can be easily accessible from phenols or anilines. 2,5‐Cyclohexadienones serve as an “aromatic to be” synthon with multiple electrophilic centres, providing an opportunity towards their functionalization. While mono‐functionalization was widely explored and covered in literature, simultaneous dual functionalizations with two distinct coupling partners offer a powerful strategy for rapid molecular diversification around aromatic rings. Diverse functional groups/coupling partners have been introduced chemo‐ and regio‐selectively. The synthetic processes adopted are generally sustainable and free from transition metals and exotic conditions. This review showcased the advancement in developing dual functionalizations of phenols/anilines for the site‐selective synthesis of multi‐functional arenes through an aromaticity‐destruction‐functionalization‐construction strategy.
item.content:encoded:

This strategy proceeds via 2,5-cyclohexadienones and 2,5-cyclohexadienimines intermediates and permits a wide range of functionalizations with various coupling partners, enabling rapid molecular diversification under sustainable and transition metal-free conditions.


Abstract

Dual functionalizations of arenes promise to remain a powerful and versatile strategy for the synthesis of complex molecules with diverse applications in various fields. Dearomatization-Functionalization-rearomatization strategy emerges as a versatile tool for chemo- and regioselective functionalization of arenes via 2,5-cyclohexadienone/2,5-cyclohexadienimines, which can be easily accessible from phenols or anilines. 2,5-Cyclohexadienones serve as an “aromatic to be” synthon with multiple electrophilic centres, providing an opportunity towards their functionalization. While mono-functionalization was widely explored and covered in literature, simultaneous dual functionalizations with two distinct coupling partners offer a powerful strategy for rapid molecular diversification around aromatic rings. Diverse functional groups/coupling partners have been introduced chemo- and regio-selectively. The synthetic processes adopted are generally sustainable and free from transition metals and exotic conditions. This review showcased the advancement in developing dual functionalizations of phenols/anilines for the site-selective synthesis of multi-functional arenes through an aromaticity-destruction-functionalization-construction strategy.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Advancements in the Synthesis of Oxadiazines, Mechanistic insights and Pathways
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review explores the synthesis and mechanistic pathways of oxadiazines, highlighting their significance in organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, and industry. Recent advancements in metal‐catalyzed, organocatalytic, and green approaches are examined, along with key strategies such as cycloaddition and oxidative annulation, etc. Mechanistic insights into intermediates, transition states, and catalyst roles are discussed to refine synthetic pathways and enhance efficiency.
Abstract Oxadiazine has the distinctive structure of a six‐membered heterocyclic ring with two nitrogen and one oxygen atoms. This molecule has lately gained substantial attention due to its promising uses in several sectors, including medicines, agrochemicals, and material science. As a result, the synthesis of oxadiazine is extensively explored for its application in pharmaceuticals, pest control, and medical treatments due to its antibacterial, anticancer, anti‐inflammatory and insecticidal effects. In this review, we provided a comprehensive overview of oxadiazine‘s synthetic strategies and mechanistic aspects, prioritizing the various novel methods developed for synthesising oxadiazine. We demonstrated the synthesis of various oxadiazine derivatives such as 1,3,4‐, 1,3,5‐, 1,2,4‐, 1,2,5‐oxadiazines and the functionalization of this molecule to enhance their bioactivity. In this study, we discussed an overview of synthetic routes, such as cyclization reactions, cycloaddition reactions, catalyst‐free and solvent‐free reactions, triflate‐catalyzed reactions, etc. We highlighted the challenges faced in the reported synthesis, suitable reaction conditions, substrate scope and applications.
item.content:encoded:

Recent advancements in metal-catalyzed, organocatalytic, and green approaches are examined, along with key strategies such as cycloaddition and oxidative annulation, etc. Mechanistic insights into intermediates, transition states, and catalyst roles are discussed to refine synthetic pathways and enhance efficiency.


Abstract

Oxadiazine has the distinctive structure of a six-membered heterocyclic ring with two nitrogen and one oxygen atoms. This molecule has lately gained substantial attention due to its promising uses in several sectors, including medicines, agrochemicals, and material science. As a result, the synthesis of oxadiazine is extensively explored for its application in pharmaceuticals, pest control, and medical treatments due to its antibacterial, anticancer, anti-inflammatory and insecticidal effects. In this review, we provided a comprehensive overview of oxadiazine‘s synthetic strategies and mechanistic aspects, prioritizing the various novel methods developed for synthesising oxadiazine. We demonstrated the synthesis of various oxadiazine derivatives such as 1,3,4-, 1,3,5-, 1,2,4-, 1,2,5-oxadiazines and the functionalization of this molecule to enhance their bioactivity. In this study, we discussed an overview of synthetic routes, such as cyclization reactions, cycloaddition reactions, catalyst-free and solvent-free reactions, triflate-catalyzed reactions, etc. We highlighted the challenges faced in the reported synthesis, suitable reaction conditions, substrate scope and applications.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Transition Metal‐Promoted Direct C‐S and C‐Se Bond Formation from Csp3‐H Bonds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The transition metal‐catalyzed direct C−S and C−Se bond formation from C−H bonds has emerged as an efficient synthetic strategy for constructing previously inaccessible organochalcogen compounds, opening a new gateway to late‐stage functionalization of pharmaceutical‐relevant molecules and organic functional materials. C−Y bonds (Y = S, Se, Te) also show outstanding strategic relevance as handles to access other valuable functional groups downstream in a synthetic route. Despite the significant progress, the chemo‐, site‐, and enantioselective C−S and C−Se bond formation from unactivated Csp3−H bonds is still challenging owing to its low polarity and inertness. Here, we provide a comprehensive overview of the transition‐metal‐catalyzed direct conversion of unactivated Csp3−H to C−S and C−Se bonds in the last decade, looking to motivate the continuous discovery of innovative and efficient systems for these transformations.

Despite the significant progress, the chemo-, site-, and enantioselective C−S and C−Se bond formation from unactivated Csp3−H bonds is still challenging owing to its low polarity and inertness. Here, we provide a comprehensive overview of the transition-metal-catalyzed direct conversion of unactivated Csp3−H to C−S and C−Se bonds in the last decade, looking to motivate the continuous discovery of innovative and efficient systems for these transformations.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Organocatalytic γ,γ‐Regioselective Formal (1+5) Cycloaddition of Isoindolinone‐Derived Propargylic Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An organocatalytic γ,γ‐regioselective formal (1+5) cycloaddition of isoindolinone‐derived propargylic alcohols with 2‐indolylphenols was established, which afforded a series of indole‐fused chromanes in overall good yields. This work not only established the first γ,γ‐regioselective (1+n) cycloaddition of isoindolinone‐derived propargylic alcohols, but also provided a good example of 1,5‐CO‐regioselective (5+1) cycloadditions involving 2‐indolylphenols for the synthesis of indole‐fused chromanes.
Abstract An organocatalytic γ,γ‐regioselective formal (1+5) cycloaddition of isoindolinone‐derived propargylic alcohols with 2‐indolylphenols was established, which afforded a series of indole‐fused chromanes with potential antitumor activity in overall good yields (up to 99 %). A tandem cycloaddition process was proposed based on detailed control experiments. Moreover, biological evaluation demonstrates the promising application of indole‐fused chromanes. This work not only established the first γ,γ‐regioselective (1+n) cycloaddition of isoindolinone‐derived propargylic alcohols, but also provided a good example of 1,5‐CO‐regioselective (5+1) cycloadditions involving 2‐indolylphenols for the synthesis of indole‐fused chromanes with potential biological activity.
item.content:encoded:
An organocatalytic γ,γ-regioselective formal (1+5) cycloaddition of isoindolinone-derived propargylic alcohols with 2-indolylphenols was established, which afforded a series of indole-fused chromanes in overall good yields. This work not only established the first γ,γ-regioselective (1+n) cycloaddition of isoindolinone-derived propargylic alcohols, but also provided a good example of 1,5-CO-regioselective (5+1) cycloadditions involving 2-indolylphenols for the synthesis of indole-fused chromanes.


Abstract

An organocatalytic γ,γ-regioselective formal (1+5) cycloaddition of isoindolinone-derived propargylic alcohols with 2-indolylphenols was established, which afforded a series of indole-fused chromanes with potential antitumor activity in overall good yields (up to 99 %). A tandem cycloaddition process was proposed based on detailed control experiments. Moreover, biological evaluation demonstrates the promising application of indole-fused chromanes. This work not only established the first γ,γ-regioselective (1+n) cycloaddition of isoindolinone-derived propargylic alcohols, but also provided a good example of 1,5-CO-regioselective (5+1) cycloadditions involving 2-indolylphenols for the synthesis of indole-fused chromanes with potential biological activity.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Three‐Component Radical Strategy for the Synthesis of β‐Amino Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This study presents a visible‐light‐mediated three‐component radical reaction involving alcohols or alkanes and in situ‐formed imines. The imines, generated from aldehydes and amines, serve as key reactants, while the inexpensive and readily available sodium decatungstate (NaDT) is employed as a photocatalyst. This strategy enables the functionalization of industrially accessible alcohols or alkanes to synthesize β‐amino alcohols via an intermolecular hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) mechanism under visible‐light irradiation. The reaction is operationally simple, exhibits high conversion efficiency, facilitates straightforward post‐reaction processing, and demonstrates excellent atom and step economy.

This strategy enables the functionalization of industrially accessible alcohols or alkanes to synthesize β‐amino alcohols via an intermolecular hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) mechanism under visible‐light irradiation. The reaction is operationally simple, exhibits high conversion efficiency, facilitates straightforward post‐reaction processing, and demonstrates excellent atom and step economy.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iron‐Catalyzed Markovnikov Hydration of Unactivated Terminal Alkenes Enabled by Reductive Radical‐Polar Crossover
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Herein, we describe a convenient and general method for the Markovnikov oxidation of unactivated olefins to alcohols and ketones using commercially available iron acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3) as catalysts, and cheap phenylsilane PhSiH3 as reducing agent. All reactions proceed efficiently at room temperature with air as sole oxidant. The alcohols are formed smoothly in up to >80 % isolated yield and with 100 % regioselectivity for secondary alcohols formation, while the corresponding ketones were observed as by‐products.
Abstract Herein, we describe a simple and convenient protocol for the Markovnikov oxidation of unactivated olefins to alcohols and ketones using readily available iron salt Fe(acac)3 as a catalyst, and phenylsilane PhSiH3 as reducing material. All reactions proceed efficiently at mild conditions with air as terminal oxidant. This transformation has been applied to a variety of substrates, and is distinguished by its simplicity, mild temperatures and broad scope. The alcohols are formed smoothly in up to >80 % isolated yield and with 100 % regioselectivity for secondary alcohols formation, while the corresponding ketones were observed as by‐products.
item.content:encoded:

All reactions proceed efficiently at room temperature with air as sole oxidant. The alcohols are formed smoothly in up to >80 % isolated yield and with 100 % regioselectivity for secondary alcohols formation, while the corresponding ketones were observed as by-products.


Abstract

Herein, we describe a simple and convenient protocol for the Markovnikov oxidation of unactivated olefins to alcohols and ketones using readily available iron salt Fe(acac)3 as a catalyst, and phenylsilane PhSiH3 as reducing material. All reactions proceed efficiently at mild conditions with air as terminal oxidant. This transformation has been applied to a variety of substrates, and is distinguished by its simplicity, mild temperatures and broad scope. The alcohols are formed smoothly in up to >80 % isolated yield and with 100 % regioselectivity for secondary alcohols formation, while the corresponding ketones were observed as by-products.

item.dc:title: Iron‐Catalyzed Markovnikov Hydration of Unactivated Terminal Alkenes Enabled by Reductive Radical‐Polar Crossover

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Cascade Reactions of Enone‐Tethered Ketones and Aldehydes with Indoles: Substrate‐Controlled Divergent Synthesis of Indenes and Indanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A diversity‐oriented one‐pot synthesis of indenes and indanes has been realized under benign metal‐free conditions. The Michael–Aldol cascade process involving reactions of enone‐tethered ketones with indoles to readily access indenes is demonstrated in the presence of iodine as a catalyst. However, a reaction sequence that involves Michael–Aldol, and nucleophilic substitution gives indanes bearing indole moieties by employing enone‐tethered aldehyde as a reaction partner with indoles.
Abstract A cascade strategy involving the reactions of enone‐tethered ketones with indoles for the synthesis of indenes is outlined in the presence of iodine as a catalyst. Halogen bonding between molecular iodine and enones activates substrates to undergo Michael addition with indoles, resulting in the formation of enolates. These enolates in situ are transformed into indenes via an intramolecular aldol condensation. Enone‐tethered aldehydes, however, react with two molecules of indoles to give indanes through a reaction sequence that involves chemoselective Michael addition followed by intramolecular aldol, and nucleophilic substitution. The substrate‐controlled diversity‐oriented synthesis has been realized to readily access indenes and indanes bearing indole moieties under benign metal‐free conditions. The compatibility of these reactions has also been tested with a scale‐up reaction for practical applications.

However, a reaction sequence that involves Michael–Aldol, and nucleophilic substitution gives indanes bearing indole moieties by employing enone-tethered aldehyde as a reaction partner with indoles.


Abstract

These enolates in situ are transformed into indenes via an intramolecular aldol condensation. Enone-tethered aldehydes, however, react with two molecules of indoles to give indanes through a reaction sequence that involves chemoselective Michael addition followed by intramolecular aldol, and nucleophilic substitution. The substrate-controlled diversity-oriented synthesis has been realized to readily access indenes and indanes bearing indole moieties under benign metal-free conditions. The compatibility of these reactions has also been tested with a scale-up reaction for practical applications.
